story:
Project Summary

We are three Toronto-based dance artists who have come together after years of collaboration to premiere three contemporary dance works in a full-evening production entitled episodes l andscapes. This DanceWorks CoWorks Series Event runs April 4-6, 2013 at the Dancemakers Centre for Creation in Toronto. The works explore themes of memory, locality and intimacy as we invite our audience to surrender to the dynamic terrains of the human experience. Our goal with this project is to challenge ourselves as artists while creating a visceral and lasting performance experience for our audience.

We are committed to the next generation of dance artists and audiences and will have matinees for high-school students with post-performance Q & A's, as well as a variety of educational workshops as part of our community outreach.

indiegogo Campaign

This campaign will directly support the final creation stage of each of the works prior to their production and presentation. We are raising funds to cover the rental of rehearsal space, (approximately 100 hours or 30-35 hrs per piece at $20 per hr) as well as the final costume, set and sound designs. This campaign is only one of our many fundraising efforts and every dollar raised will go directly into the final creation phase of each work. If we do not reach our goal of $2,000 we will proceed with this project and continue fundraising! 

* a contribution of $20 will support 1 hour in the studio.                                                                        

* a contribution of $50 will support 2.5 hours in the studio and you will receive a set of unique dance-themed postcards.                                                                                                                              

* a contribution of $100 will support the construction of 1 costume and you will   receive an original hand-crafted pair of earrings designed and constructed by Jesse Dell.                                               

* a contribution of $200 will support the final construction of our set and you will receive a beautiful 8 x 10 framed photograph by Carlyle Creative – you can select the image of your choice from our gallery, see details in the ‘perks’ section.

Every little bit helps!

Even if you are not able to make a financial contribution at this time, you can still
help us by spreading the word about our show and this campaign. Please share this page on your social networking pages with the indiegogo share tools and get the word out about this great project!

About Us

Collectively, we have been creating and presenting our own work for over a decade.
Each of us has successfully raised the revenue to support our past projects and to do this we've often called upon the support of our friends, family and dance-loving community.

Please consider contributing to this great project and supporting local independent dance artists!

story:
Starchild Dance Lindy Hop Project

Greetings, my name is Traci Bartlow I and I LOVE to Lindy Hop!  I became intrigued with this dance when as a child my mother took me to the Black filmmakers Film Festival in Oakland, CA and we viewed dance and music films of the Harlem Renaissance. Since that time and through out my career as a dancer I learned and performed this form of authentic jazz dances.

As a dancer and choreographer I've had a great career and I'm proficent in many styles of including jazz, hip hop, and afircan dance. It all started with me learning funk and soul social dances in the 1970's, I trained professionally at the Alvin Ailey American Center in New York City and, I've worked in countless dance companies, productions, theater engagments, films and, video.  When I began teaching the history and culture of Hip Hop dance in the Bay Area more than 10 years ago, I've always included the Harlem Renaissance as a foundation of hip hop dance and culture.

My dance company Starchild Dance is seeking funding to support our Lindy Hop projects.  We are building a Lindy Hop inspired dance team and are creating a short film based on this work.  The funding from this campaign help will support: artist fees for training, creating new work and rehearsals, renting rehearsal space, and filmming our efforts to create a film short, "Oakland is Hellzapoppin!"

Your contributions will help this dream manifest into a reality.  I have been teaching and perfoming Lindy Hop in Oakland for more than 10 years and I'm excited to give light to this beautiful community of artist and musicians.

What We Need & What You Get

I actually need way more than $10,000 but I hope to secure this amount and also work on matching funds. This money will be used for artist fees; dancers, choreographers, directors, musicians, filmmaker and editor. What you get is a big shout out in our short film and, we have really cool Oakland is Hellzapoppin' T-shirts to give away. There are also free Lindy Hop classes with yours truly, ME! And, for the larger donors I will host a jazz and bbq luncheon in my beautiful backyard garden in West Oakland!
 

The Impact

As a cultural worker my art and creativity is used to heal and empower my community serving as a vehicle for social change.  This this project will greatly impact the black community not only in Oakland but worldwide as we honor and celebrate an incredible dance that comes from the black experience.

Other Ways You Can Help

Starchild Entertainment can always use the support of volunteers and inkind donations. Please like my page on Facebook and send me a message to know other ways you can support. http://www.facebook.com/StarchildEntertainment....

story:
Help us send Ky to JUMP!

My daughter is a dancer. 

Kylie has been dancing since she was three years old.  She is now 13.  She is a beautiful and bright young lady.  She pays her way through her classes, as well as her younger sister’s classes, by assisting her teacher in other dance classes.  She has been doing this for two years now and she loves it.  She calls the little ones “my students” and takes pride in helping each and every one of them become a better dancer.

Kylie has asked to attend the local JUMP Dance Convention coming up in April 2013.  She attended last year (which was her first year), but got sick on her last day and was unable to attend the workshops she signed up for.  She was devastated, as Mia Michaels’ class was one of the classes she missed.

Kylie is an awesome kid and she works hard at everything she does.  We homeschool both of our daughters as this gives them the opportunity to learn and grow at their own pace, while being able to nurture their creative sides (Kylie also does karate and draws anime!). 

This year has been especially hard on our family in a number of ways.  In order for us to make the JUMP convention this coming year, we need your help.  Here is the breakdown of what we need:

JUMP Registration fee:  $205
JUMP Observer Fee:  $40 (only one is needed)
JUMP Hotel fee:  $200 per night (x2)= $400
Gas:  $50
(1) JUMP Souvenir:  $50
Parking:  $60
Food:  $400

TOTAL:  $1,205 + IGG fees of approximately $95 (if we make our goal), so our actual request is $1,300.

Perks will be simple:  Updates, thank you cards, and pictures of our Dancer Girl doing her thing. 

If you cannot donate, it is truly okay.  I appreciate you taking the time to read all about our campaign.  The one thing you CAN do for us though…share.  Share, share, share to your heart’s content, as this will help us keep the momentum going once we start getting donations.

Thank you again!

Mama Michele

story:
The Accidental Shakespeare Company is a new classical theater company in Chicago. The Accidentals want to bring a high level of dramaturgy and acting skills to an affordable storefront theater space. We are raising money for our first main stage show, The Tempest. We are raising the funds to cover the production costs so that we can maintain a very affordable ticket price for all.

The Tempest is a show about magic and most productions make the show about the magical stuff, the spectacle and the show. We like spectacle as much as anybody, but what makes our show unique is that we put the magic into the context it would have had in the early 17th century. Our design team has invented what we call “Alchemy Punk”: like Cyberpunk or Steampunk, but powered by wind and magic. So-called magicians, astrologers and alchemists were just discovering elementary physics, chemistry, astronomy, and navigation. Do not be confused by all the talk of spirits. Scholars of the natural world studied the supernatural with the same intensity. Fairies and elves and witches were believed to be every bit as much a part of the natural world as Mendel’s peas or Galileo’s stars. Furthermore, Christendom had been in flames for a century over issues of faith. Their culture, like ours, hovers on the brink of overwhelming change, and not all of those changes were good.

 The Tempest touches on issues with such contemporary resonance that legislators in Arizona have banned the teaching of it in the public school system. They think the play is provocative. They are right.

We as a company are committed to low ticket costs, so that people who cannot afford the high ticket prices of many Chicago theaters will be able to come to our show. To achieve this goal, we need to raise the remaining third of our desired budget, $4,000. We could mount the production with the two thirds we have already raised, but currently our designers have very tight budgets, and are working with us for less than they can get in other productions.  The remaining $4,000 would ensure better stipends for our actors and designers, as well as fill out our designer's budgets.

remember any amount however small is a help us reach our goal and you will have our gratitude. The perks are suggested amounts only, but you can contribute any amount.

If you are unable to contribute you can still help:

Share this campaign with your friends,- be sure to use Indiegogo's share tools.

Follow us on Twitter (@accshakes) and like us on Facebook 

Spread the word about Accidental Shakespeare Company and our alchemy punk Tempest.

And last but not least come see our show.

story:
OUR STORY

It has always been a dream of ours to give Boogiezone - YOUR Online Dance Community Connection (Est. 2003) a physical home. To find a space for all of our Southern California dancers to come dance, learn, inspire, and create. At Boogiezone Utopia - Torrance, we encourage everyone to imagine what their ideal personal Utopian state of creative existence would be, and allow each to explore it further by not only providing the space, the but tools and the environment to help make dreams happen. Many dancers and artists have the vision to be exceptional, however, they do not have the resources to nurture it. We want to continue offering this resource to all aspiring dancers in the community, and truly believe that Boogiezone Utopia is the key to so many hopes and dreams!

Our goal is to continue with our vision to create this Utopian dance community. Our team has put in so much time, effort, and what we like to call "sweat equity" into this studio thus far. Now, we would like your help to bring us closer to our dream. 

THE IMPACT

We have already started transforming the studio in Torrance to make it a welcoming and nurturing environment for all dancers in the area and from afar - we are global, with a massive reach. If we achieve this transformation process, we will be able to really foster the growth and development of young, aspiring and professional dancers. We have started something amazing, we just need a boost of support and help to continue on our journey. We know it will not happen over night, so we hope that in the next 60 days, we will be able to complete our goals and reach our vision.

If our campaign isn't successful, we may not get to truly see our vision come to life. At this moment, we have touched the surface of what we want to do with the studio, it is now, that we need to get under the surface to really bring out Boogiezone Utopia's true potential. You can help us reach this potential. 

WHAT WE NEED AND WHAT YOU GET

We need pledges and donations. Anything and everything helps! Any donation level is accepted!! We will definitely repay the favor. Our goal is to raise at least $2500 for studio equipment. To get quality speakers and proper air circulation installed in our 7 studios. All donations have incentives! These are just the base incentives as well!! We will be more than happy to cater to your needs for your donation! 

PLEDGE

INCENTIVE


$1

A Boogiezone Thank You! Shoutout! Online/Newsletter


$5

A Boogiezone Gift. + Thank You!


$10

A BZ Community Class Dance Pass + Thank You!


$25

A Week of BZ Community Classes (3 Classes)


$50

Limited Edition BZ Utopia T-Shirt + 3 BZ Utopia Classes


$75

Special Edition BZ Shirt + A BZ New Era Hat + 1 BZ Community Classes


$100

Two Week Utopia Buffet (All you can Dance Pass!)





OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP


Here is how you can help! All dancers in the community, friends of dancers, and anyone who understands our vision can contribute.  Anyone who has ever taken a Boogiezone Community Class, come to Hype Studios, Boogiezone Utopia, or danced for Breed, Offpsring, or Entity, here is what you can do! Give back to your Boogiezone Family.  Think about all the wonderful experiences, memories, and bonds you have created through Boogiezone.  Now is the time to say Thank you to Boogiezone.  Donate, spread the word on facebook, twitter, e-mail, tell your friends, family, and be proud to represent Boogiezone. We need all the help we can get to make this dream come true!

story:
Our Story

Hello, I'm Amanda 'Kat' Shaw also known as Whirling Tam Lin. I am a performance artist in the Genesee County area of Michigan. Recently my car was broken into and my performance tools were stolen. I'm starting this campaign so that I may replace them with something better and get back to work.

 

The Impact

I love being able to go out ad perform on the streets of Flint. I like to believe that my being out there has inspired others to take the first step into a larger world. Whatever that world may be. I deeply love the world of performance art and and deeply hurt by the loss of my ability to go out and share my world with others. I seek to use some of these funds to make simple poi and start teaching others the joys and healing of flow.

 

What We Need & What You Get

The first thing I'm going to do is replace my LED poi, my contact juggling ball and my Toroflux that were stolen from my car. After that all of the funds are going towards making some simple practice poi and renting a location to start teaching others in this area. I'm also looking into pulling in other instructors of other aspects of the performance arts. Even if I do not reach my full goal I'm going to be doing moving forward on this project.
 
Every person who makes a donation will receive a Thank you card with a promotional code good for a discount off anything from Unseelie Designs ( http://www.etsy.com/shop/UnseelieDesigns ). 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you cannot donate yourself (and don't worry if you find you can't) please share this project with your friends. Link backs sent across Twitter, Facebook and G+ are very appreciated.

story:
About THE EDEN PROJECT

  • Out of hundreds of submissions, Stable Cable's THE EDEN PROJECT was chosen as one the twenty-two plays presented in the Dream Up Festival at Theater for the New City!  THE EDEN PROJECT has been granted five performances at Theater for the New City’s beautiful Community Space Theater, a ninety-nine-seat theater on the Lower East Side of Manhattan.  Our ensemble is honored and thrilled to have our world premiere of THE EDEN PROJECT presented by Theater for the New City, which has won over forty-two Village Voice Obie Awards for excellence in every theatrical discipline, five ASCAP Awards, and a Pulitzer Prize for Drama for Sam Shepard’s Buried Child, which was commissioned and presented by TNC. 

  • About Stabe Cable: We are an ensemble-based company of emerging theater artists who create experimental and multi-disciplinary works.  Our mission is to devise and foster new work as an ensemble, investigate the audience/actor relationship and challenge ourselves by exploring different theatrical forms.  We strive to move people through the communal experience that is unique to live performance.  

The Eden Project is directed by Seth Hamlin and choreographed by KC Luce.

The cast includes Lisa Jill Anderson, Emily Daly, Brian Edelman, Emmanuel Elpenord, Breanna Foister, Chelsea Gonzalez, Matt Helm, Cory Kosel, Matthew McGill, Sarah Fallon Moran, Cristina Pitter,  Heather Lee Rogers, and Gillian Rougier.

Scenic Design:  Doss Freel

Costume Design:  Bridget Gavlin

Lighting Design:  Isaac Winston

Sound Design:  Zane Brzezinski

Production Stage Manager: Catherine Fowles

 

We need your help!

  • As the presenters of THE EDEN PROJECT, Theater for the New City will provide the venue for our upcoming performances.  Additionally, Stable Cable Lab Co. was granted a month of rehearsal space from the non-profit theater organization The Field, as part of their Summer Dreaming residency program.  However, we still need financial help for crucial production elements including costumes, set pieces, props, and lighting instruments. These production elements play a major role in creating the atmosphere for both audience and performer and our play will not be complete without them.  We also need to provide stipidens for our fabulous production team!

Our Budget Break-Down:

  • $700 to costume sixteen characters.  Characters include G.O.D. the Drag Queen, Lilith, Adam, Eve, Samael, Mrs. Lion, Mrs. Lamb, Tiff, Steph, and the Seven Deadly Sins Chorus.
  • $500 for set pieces and props.  Act 1 takes place in a 1950s paradise housing development and Act 2 is in a wild nightclub!
  • $40 for lighting gels to create the picture-perfect 1950s world and the nightclub atmosphere.
  • $400 for designer stipends ($100 each)
  • $200 for stage manager stipend
  • $160 for marketing: we need postcards and posters to plaster around NYC to get people to come to our awesome show!

Grand total: $2,000

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Post a link to our campaign on your Facebook Page!
  • Attend our fundraisers on Aug. 7 and Aug. 14 (see the Stable Cable Facebook Page for more information)
  • Like Stable Cable on Facebook and follow us on Twitter and spread the word about THE EDEN PROJECT!
story_txt:
About THE EDEN PROJECT


Out of hundreds of submissions, Stable Cable's THE EDEN PROJECT was chosen as one the twenty-two plays presented in the Dream Up Festival at Theater for the New City!  THE EDEN PROJECT has been granted five performances at Theater for the New City’s beautiful Community Space Theater, a ninety-nine-seat theater on the Lower East Side of Manhattan.  Our ensemble is honored and thrilled to have our world premiere of THE EDEN PROJECT presented by Theater for the New City, which has won over forty-two Village Voice Obie Awards for excellence in every theatrical discipline, five ASCAP Awards, and a Pulitzer Prize for Drama for Sam Shepard’s Buried Child, which was commissioned and presented by TNC. 

About Stabe Cable: We are an ensemble-based company of emerging theater artists who create experimental and multi-disciplinary works.  Our mission is to devise and foster new work as an ensemble, investigate the audience/actor relationship and challenge ourselves by exploring different theatrical forms.  We strive to move people through the communal experience that is unique to live performance.  

The Eden Project is directed by Seth Hamlin and choreographed by KC Luce.
The cast includes Lisa Jill Anderson, Emily Daly, Brian Edelman, Emmanuel Elpenord, Breanna Foister, Chelsea Gonzalez, Matt Helm, Cory Kosel, Matthew McGill, Sarah Fallon Moran, Cristina Pitter,  Heather Lee Rogers, and Gillian Rougier.
Scenic Design:  Doss Freel
Costume Design:  Bridget Gavlin
Lighting Design:  Isaac Winston
Sound Design:  Zane Brzezinski
Production Stage Manager: Catherine Fowles
 


We need your help!




As the presenters of THE EDEN PROJECT, Theater for the New City will provide the venue for our upcoming performances.  Additionally, Stable Cable Lab Co. was granted a month of rehearsal space from the non-profit theater organization The Field, as part of their Summer Dreaming residency program.  However, we still need financial help for crucial production elements including costumes, set pieces, props, and lighting instruments. These production elements play a major role in creating the atmosphere for both audience and performer and our play will not be complete without them.  We also need to provide stipidens for our fabulous production team!


Our Budget Break-Down:

$700 to costume sixteen characters.  Characters include G.O.D. the Drag Queen, Lilith, Adam, Eve, Samael, Mrs. Lion, Mrs. Lamb, Tiff, Steph, and the Seven Deadly Sins Chorus.
$500 for set pieces and props.  Act 1 takes place in a 1950s paradise housing development and Act 2 is in a wild nightclub!
$40 for lighting gels to create the picture-perfect 1950s world and the nightclub atmosphere.
$400 for designer stipends ($100 each)
$200 for stage manager stipend
$160 for marketing: we need postcards and posters to plaster around NYC to get people to come to our awesome show!

Grand total: $2,000


Other Ways You Can Help

Post a link to our campaign on your Facebook Page!
Attend our fundraisers on Aug. 7 and Aug. 14 (see the Stable Cable Facebook Page for more information)
Like Stable Cable on Facebook and follow us on Twitter and spread the word about THE EDEN PROJECT!

story:
Of her critically acclaimed solo evening at Danspace Project, The New York Times said “Ms. Velez-Jackson demonstrates her own formidable presence as she bursts into the space….A choreographer who is not afraid of being (or showing) ugly onstage, she disarms her audiences with humor..."

Hi. I'm Larissa Velez-Jackson,

Choreographer, theater-director and comedic dance provocateur. I'm also one of two Americans selected from 1023 applicants from all over the world for this year’s danceWeb Scholarship program in Vienna. This would be a dream come true for me: 5 weeks of intensive study of contemporary performance with the greatest artists from all over the world at ImPulsTanz, Vienna International Dance Festival. To exchange ideas with global artists, teachers and a 1-on-1 artistic mentor at this level would be massively impactful on my career.  It is sure to be a life-changing experience and I'd like to share it with you! Here is what I plan to create as the fruits of my experience in Vienna:

LARISSA REPORTS ON IMPULSTANZ!

I will chronicle my time in residency in a special Viennablog, chock-full of photos, video, songs, movement scores, and notes from week-long intensive workshops (such as a writing workshop with Claudia LaRocco of The New York Times and Voguing with the incredible Archie Burnett). Most importantly, I will broadcast a weekly video show on the Internet during my residency where I'll report on all the creative, exciting, unpredictable things that go on at this wonderful artist/residency/festival/extravaganza. I hope to interview art stars of the European dance world, as well as tell you all the behind-the-scenes tour jetes! As project backers, you'll have a stake in my process, with opportunities to make requests of my reporting, learn about and even ask questions of European dance celebrities at the festival. You’ll also get regular updates about my month-long experience and receive personalized thank-you's featured in the blog. I will literally be taking you all to Europe with me. I really need your contributions to get me there!!!!

 

WHY RAISE $ IF I'VE ALREADY BEEN AWARDED THE SCHOLARSHIP???

In order to participate in the program, I need to secure the co-funding of my scholarship. This 1/3 of the scholarship ($2,850) needs to be provided by June 1st, 2012.

Unlike European participants who get government funding, participants from America generally have to secure private donations from family, friends, and amazing supporters like you. In moments like these, I must look to my near and dear community to help make my dream come true! The upside is that with this IndiGoGo campaign, I'll be able to bring all of you with me on this exciting adventure!

 
BUDGET

$2,850 -1/3 of the danceWEB program cost

$1050 - My meals for 5 weeks (not included in scholarship)

$3900 total

Thanks for taking the time to listen and I hope that with your contribution I can be an ambassador (and happy troublemaker) from Newark, New Jersey, making awesome things happen in Vienna.



The Rewards for Giving!!!!

 

Check out only some of the one-of-a-kind rewards donated by my favorite teachers and highly-esteemed colleagues for my project campaign. I truly see this IndiGoGo campaign as a brilliant piece of social choreography that can create spirit and health-expanding experiences for all of us from start to finish!

$60: 25 min phone consultation on "Clean Eating" with Stephanie Velez PT, DPT - If interested in the nutrition consultation, please be ready to share your goals in either fitness or nutrition with Stephanie Velez, PT, DPT. She's  been a physical therapist in an acute-care hospital setting and acted as team leader for the Burn Rehabilitation team at Temple University Hospital. She studied nutrition in regards to burn care and wound healing. Her independent study of nutrition has been through a varied health and fitness journey, which lead her to incorporate "Clean Eating". 

$150: Private Session in Pilates/Gentle Yoga/Fitness or Ballroom and    $300: Home 2-8 person session with Larissa Velez-Jackson.Larissa teaches a wide variety of group fitness and mind/body modalities that cater to students’ specific needs and strengths. She is certified in Kane School Pilates (2009), AFAA Group Fitness, Pilates Institute of America Mat Certified, Rasa Yoga Certified (2005), Arthur Murray Ballroom Dance Certified (2000), and current CPR/AED. She has taught at 92 St Y and West Side Y in Manhattan for seven years. For more info on her classes: http://larissavelez.com/teaching.html

$150: Home Pilates Session and Ayurvedic Back Treatment with Hilary Clark. Hilary has been studying Pilates for over 15 years and completed the highest level certification in Pilates with Deborah Lessen, Pilates Method Alliance board president, at Greene Street Studio in New York City. Her studies and influences also include Yoga, Ayurveda, ideokinesis, Body Mind Centering, and other movement modalities. Hilary has taught at Finetune Pilates in Brooklyn since 2002 and is a certified practitioner of Wise Earth Ayurveda. (http://www.wisearth.org/ayurveda/index.html)

$150: BodyTalk Session with Christine McEwan. Christine is a sought-after Pilates and Gyrotonic teacher and BodyTalk practitioner in NYC for 15 years. "BodyTalk is an astonishingly simple and effective holistic therapy that allows the body's energy systems to be re-synchronized so they can operate as nature intended...It stimulates the body's innate ability to balance and heal itself on all levels." -International BodyTalk Association http://www.bodytalksystem.com/learn/bodytalk/

---------------------------

Here is the break down of what I'm receiving as part of danceWeb. You'll see what an incredible gift and honor this is for an emerging choreographer like me!

  • Individual coaching by the danceWEB artistic mentors Benoît Lachambre (CA) & Robin Poitras (CA)
  • Participation in the research projects of ImPulsTanz 2012 (ProSeries and CoachingProjects)
  • Participation in the technique workshops of ImPulsTanz 2012 
  • Free Admission to all performances of ImPulsTanz 2012
  • Free Accommodation in Vienna for the period of the Scholarship Programme (single or double room)
  • Free Access to approx. 300 awarded dance film videos as well as to screenings of documentations and to the dance film productions of artists and companies who perform at the ImPulsTanz
  • Exchange of ideas and contact with the international teachers and choreographers of ImPulsTanz 2012
  • Lecture demonstrations & talks
  • Special projects exclusively offered to danceWEB scholarship holders
  • representation in the yearly growing, international danceWEB-database at www.jardindeurope.eu

Please help me fulfill this great honor! I can't do it without YOU!

Thank You!

story:
About "How Deep Is the Ocean?"

It's summer and the temperature's rising when suddenly every beach on the Jersey Shore is threatened with closure: The water is too polluted for swimming!  That is until Rob -- a small town pool technician -- stumbles upon an opportunity to chlorinate the ocean. But when a local handy man's lust for power and revenge threatens Rob's world, the two rivals are thrust into battle to restore the ocean and win the heart of  a woman they both love. A musical comedy about love, lust, and chlorine.

Despite the comedic overtones and unique premise, How Deep Is The Ocean? is a coming of age story about 3 people at a crossroads in their lives. It's a love triangle that explores the fears, regrets and excitement of finally having the chance to pursue a long lost dream. How Deep Is the Ocean? is funny, passionate and surprisingly realistic. 

Please check out our gallery to hear a few songs from the show.

Click here to hear some songs:

Monmouth Beach:

http://d2oadd98wnjs7n.cloudfront.net/medias/262097/files/20120607225218-MONMOUTH_BEACH.mp3?1339134746


That Kind Of Money:

http://d2oadd98wnjs7n.cloudfront.net/medias/262101/files/20120607225434-THAT_KIND_OF_MONEY.m4a?1339134903


Say Yes:

http://d2oadd98wnjs7n.cloudfront.net/medias/262099/files/20120607225332-SAY_YES.m4a?1339134851




How Deep Is The Ocean? is one of a few musicals that was invited to be a part of the prestigious New York Musical Theatre Festival (www.nymf.org) in July 2012.  This is an exciting opportunity for us to mount our first full production at this internationally renowned festival. This is our first musical, and as new musical theatre writers we are asking for your assistance to help us make this production possible. We need to raise a minimum of $30,000 to help fund our production costs.   

What we need and what your money goes towards:

We want to put on the best show possible and need your help. This fund raiser could provide us with the financial security needed to focus on all the creative decisions knowing everything has been paid for. Your contributions to this musical will be used toward:

Rental of rehearsal space                                                                     

Set pieces                                                              

Props

Costumes                         

Lighting

Sound Design

Music (including musical director and band)

And other incidental expenses that may incur when putting on a show.

 

About the writers :

Peter Cincotti (Music and Lyrics) singer-songwriter-pianist and native New Yorker, began playing piano at the age of three. By the age of 18 he was being called "one of the most promising singer-pianists of the next generation" by the New York Times.

In 2003, Peter's debut album, produced by the legendary Phil Ramone, reached #1 on the Billboard jazz charts, making Cincotti the youngest artist ever to do so. This led to acclaimed performances at Carnegie Hall, Lincoln Center, The Olympia in Paris, The Montreux Festival (where he won an award in their renowned piano competition), Queen Elizabeth Hall in London, and many other prestigious venues around the world.

Peter made his acting debut in the Kevin Spacey film Beyond The Sea, and also contributed to the film's soundtrack. He then made a cameo appearance in the blockbuster film Spider-Man 2. His original song "December Boys" was featured in the Australian film December Boys, starring Daniel Radcliffe.

In 2006, Cincotti teamed up with 14-time Grammy Award winner David Foster to record his first album of all original material for Warner Brothers Records entitled "East Of Angel Town." His single "Goodbye Philadelphia" took the airwaves by storm reaching the Top Ten on radio playlists throughout Europe, and in the Spring of 2009, Cincotti brought the album to the United States by joining the artist Seal on his sold out American tour.

Hailed as "the rebirth of cool" by Elle magazine, Peter explores musical styles that blend pop, rock, blues and jazz, infusing each new song he writes with originality and startling energy. His unparalleled piano skills and brilliantly relevant songwriting make Cincotti one of the most unique and socially aware artists in the music industry today, a sentiment that is freshly showcased on his new album "Metropolis." scheduled for release Summer of 2012.

Pia Cincotti (Book) graduated from Fordham University as a playwriting major. She was one of four people chosen to study in London at the prestigious Writer's Guild of Great Britain. Pia’s plays AFTER THE CRASH and FOUR OF A KIND had readings and staged productions at The Institute of Contemporary Arts inLondon, Fordham University in New York, The Actors Theatre of Orcas Island in Washington, and The Producers Club in New York. In October 2011, the Midtown Direct Theater Company produced the first reading of her musical  HOW DEEP IS THE OCEAN?

Thank you for any help you are able to give. Even the smallest donations go a long way toward making this production a reality.

Other Ways You Can Help

Share our campaign with fellow theaterlovers! We'd appreciate if you could post to your Facebook, Twitter, Google or email anyone who may be interested.

 NEWS:

Check out our show's article in Broadwayworld.com

http://broadwayworld.com/article/Michelle-Federer-Lavon-Fisher-Wilson-and-More-Set-for-HOW-DEEP-IS-THE-OCEAN-at-NYMF-20120606

story:
THANK YOU FOR FUNDING THIS PROJECT!

If you would still like to donate, or attend the REDCAT SHOWCASE on Fri. June 20th @ 8:30 PM, please go to www.thebigshowco.com

Short Summary

The Big Show Co. was founded in Los Angeles in 1999 by UCLA and CalArts alum, Arianne MacBean. The company creates dance-theater performance that integrates movement, text, theater and music. Rooted in a passion for communication, MacBean creates work that highlights the triumphs and failings of language - the language of the body and of text. MacBean makes work that is self-reflexive - poking fun at human failings while exposing universal vulnerabilities that are simultaneously tragic and beautiful.

Arianne MacBean & The Big Show Co. are thrilled to have been invited to perform at ODC in San Francisco. We need your help to get there!

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise at least $8,000 to cover the tour expenses. These costs include travel, per diem, housing for all four company members, our Lighting Designer/Stage Manager, and Artistic Director. In addition, money raised will cover equipment rental, theater personnel costs, publicity, and production materials.

SO, what exactly does that mean? Let us break it down for you.

$40 donation will cover the cost of one company members food for one day. Help Brad Culver get a nice chicken sandwich! ANYONE who donates $40 or more gets 1 ticket to the invitation-only LA Showcase foe The Big Show Co. at RECAT, downtown's premiere center for contemporary arts housed in the Walt Disney Concert Hall complex. Friday, June 20 at 8:30 PM.

$100 donation will costume company member, Max Eugene, for all performances. Ensure that Max does not have to dance naked!

$500 donation will cover the cost of company members, Genevieve Carson and Angelina Attwell's safe and comfortable sleeping quarters for 4 nights in SF. Help Genevieve and Angelina sleep tight!

Do you want to sponsor opening or closing night? A $2000 donation will cover all of the theater and labor costs for one night's show. Anyone who donates $2000 is credited as an Executive Producer in all publicity and programming.

See the sidebar for the unique perks you get when you participate in this exciting project!

The Impact

The SF tour and LA Showcase at REDCAT are two HUGE events for The Big Show Co. Arianne is overjoyed at the opportunity to return to her childhood stomping grounds in the Bay Area where her love of dance and theater began, and to share her art with new audiences as well as friends & family. 

Presenting a whole evening of work at REDCAT has been on the top of Arianne's "Artistic Bucket List" for years and she is honored to be able to offer contributors to this campaign the opportunity to be a part of the groundbreaking performance. The evening will also include an artist interview facilitated by Shayna Keller, Executive Director of the Dance Resource Center of Greater Los Angeles (and Arianne's former student).

The two pieces presented provide audiences the chance to see the full spectrum of Arianne's unique voice as a choreographer. The People Go Where The Chairs Are (2012) is a perfect example of The Big Show Co.'s witty, playful and irreverent dance-theater work, while the world premiere of present tense (2014) features the company's signature poetic combination of physicality and spoken word. 

With over fifteen years of experience producing, presenting and creating professional dance-theater performance, we are asking YOU to make this a BIG year for The Big Show Co.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign! Share!
  • Remember, you can use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that’s all there is to it.

These costs include travel, per diem, housing for all four company members, our Lighting Designer/Stage Manager, and Artistic Director. In addition, money raised will cover equipment rental, theater personnel costs, publicity, and production materials.SO, what exactly does that mean? Let us break it down for you.$40 donation will cover the cost of one company members food for one day. Help Brad Culver get a nice chicken sandwich! ANYONE who donates $40 or more gets 1 ticket to the invitation-only LA Showcase foe The Big Show Co. at RECAT, downtown's premiere center for contemporary arts housed in the Walt Disney Concert Hall complex. Friday, June 20 at 8:30 PM.$100 donation will costume company member, Max Eugene, for all performances. Ensure that Max does not have to dance naked!$500 donation will cover the cost of company members, Genevieve Carson and Angelina Attwell's safe and comfortable sleeping quarters for 4 nights in SF. Help Genevieve and Angelina sleep tight!Do you want to sponsor opening or closing night? A $2000 donation will cover all of the theater and labor costs for one night's show. Anyone who donates $2000 is credited as an Executive Producer in all publicity and programming.See the sidebar for the unique perks you get when you participate in this exciting project!The ImpactThe SF tour and LA Showcase at REDCAT are two HUGE events for The Big Show Co. Arianne is overjoyed at the opportunity to return to her childhood stomping grounds in the Bay Area where her love of dance and theater began, and to share her art with new audiences as well as friends & family. Presenting a whole evening of work at REDCAT has been on the top of Arianne's "Artistic Bucket List" for years and she is honored to be able to offer contributors to this campaign the opportunity to be a part of the groundbreaking performance. The evening will also include an artist interview facilitated by Shayna Keller, Executive Director of the Dance Resource Center of Greater Los Angeles (and Arianne's former student).The two pieces presented provide audiences the chance to see the full spectrum of Arianne's unique voice as a choreographer. The People Go Where The Chairs Are (2012) is a perfect example of The Big Show Co.'s witty, playful and irreverent dance-theater work, while the world premiere of present tense (2014) features the company's signature poetic combination of physicality and spoken word. With over fifteen years of experience producing, presenting and creating professional dance-theater performance, we are asking YOU to make this a BIG year for The Big Show Co.Other Ways You Can Help
Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign! Share!
Remember, you can use the Indiegogo share tools!
And that’s all there is to it.

story:
Funding Goal: $75,000

PLEASE PLEDGE AND UNITE WITH US

              ZWANANANI: THE MUSICAL

CO-CREATED BY TONY AWARD AND GRAMMY NOMINATED MUSICAL TEAMS!

"A story bound to reflect the raw emotions of human rights, war, family, romance, and the power of choice we all have within us all."         

"Zwananani for the first time, will combine the commercial film elements of Apocalypto and Avatar, bringing along The Passion of Christ, emotional strong heart throbbing film experience."

 

                               

All Donations (charitable tax-deductible)

We are working in partnership with Mr. Voza Rivers, Executive Producer at New Heritage Theater Group. http://newheritagetheater.org

Celebrating it's 50th year anniversary and recognized as the oldest African American, non-profit theater company in New York.        

Our Story

Hi everyone, I'm Jason Seto, creator of Zwananani: The Musical and Founder/Artistic President of 3PM3AM Productions. www.3pm3amproductions.com

10 years ago, I traveled to South Africa, along with my friend, Bobby Gerongco, music producer, Kuya Productions and original leading cast members of Disney's, The Lion King on Broadway.  

At that time, I envisioned recording the beautiful South African harmonies and melodies I heard, while listening to Disney's, The Lion King and SARAFINA! albums, intertwined with commercial Pop/Rock/R&B rhythmic dance music. The vision was where "Michael Jackson's History album, meets Disney's, The Lion King." We ended up laying the recording foundation for the songs "We Are One," and "Zwananani." A unique musical creation never combined before, to hit the commercial mainstream, pop audiences worldwide.

"A dream to create a unique sound and UNITE people all across the world."

 

           LISTEN TO SELECT RECORDS AND SEE FULL PROMO TRAILER         

                                             ZWANANANI: THE MUSICAL

                                   www.3pm3amproductions.com/Zwananani

                                                                                        

                                          

                                        

                                                  

Unfortunately, after recording the foundation and original ideas in South Africa, our team was hit with a life threatening car accident. While driving down a narrow road, a large truck came straight our way, not slowing down. In complete panic, the passenger tried to grab the driver’s wheel, causing our car to flip over numerous times, leaving us covered in each other's blood and near death.

Without knowing 10 years later, I see a story a few months ago on the National Geographic station, linking a study of the African indigenous tribes to our very own human existence through DNA testing, calling it "We Are One." 

 http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2005/06/0624_050624_spencerwells.html

I immediately rushed to our sound recordings and said, my god! This is our story! A story once a legend, now untold to the world. 

    "A story linking the African indigenous tribes, to our very own human existence."

Creative Development-Phase 1

To date, we have personally funded our musical sound recordings in South Africa and most recently, reproduced all of them.

 At this time, we are in development of our script with our Hollywood book writer and musical Tony nominee-South African playwright.

Our team would like to travel back to South Africa on research and script development. Once completed, we will be able to present our project to our celebrity and Broadway producer networks in January 2014.                     

    

Creative Development Expense Breakdown

                                             Authorship Advances: $30,000

                                             South Africa Plane Tickets: $10,000

                                             Hotel and Transportation: $10,000

                                             Staff Per-Diem: $5,000 (catering)

         South African Documentary Team: $5,000 (including African research consultants)

                                             Legal Fees: $15,000   

                                                       Total: $75,000

The Impact

Our Tony Award and Grammy Nominee winning collaboration creative team players have produced some of the most successful musical works ever, having come out of South Africa, to reach the world. 

The creative team credits include Disney’s, The Lion Kings music world wide, SARAFINA! and book writer to the prequel of the world wide Hollywood film The Passion of Christ.

 Our musical title song “We Are One,” will have the power to UNITE cultures and people from across the world, linking our story of the African indigenous tribes, to our very own human existence.  

“There are more than 370 million indigenous people in
   some 70 countries worldwide.

                                                      United Nations

 "It's time to share their stories"

                                                       Jason Seto

story:
Once upon a time, John Mayer started out pumping gas, strumming his guitar and writing the love songs we have come to know as uniquely his. Surely his inspiration came from somewhere, someone; perhaps from a special girl he met one summer when things were more innocent and TMZ-free. Maybe somewhere down the line he was led astray, but not during this summer when everything started to finally come together for young John Mayer, who not only longed to break out from the confines of his suburban town but also to be completely understood for the person he is.

Like John, our production team also have a dreams of following our artistic goals to fruition. We have a wonderful chance this summer as we travel to the first Hollywood Fringe Festival from June 17 to the 23rd.

Seeing as Toronto is a long way’s from LA, we definitely need help with financing our travel and accomdation expenses. We’ve had a couple of fundraisers over the last two months, but we are falling short of our needs. We are definitely starving—sometimes literally—artists here. We would appreciate any donation to assist with showcasing our work as easy as possible.

story:
Less than a week left!
Help us fund our November 2012 production of A Christmas Twist!

Just four short years ago we founded SeaGlass Theatre.  We are now one of the most critically-acclaimed theatre companies in Los Angeles.  We’re pleased for you to join us in producing more of the live theater we all wish for in LA.

In November of 2012 - SeaGlass returns to the wonderful world of literary parody with A Christmas Twist - a delightfully disturbed dissing of Dickens, for everyone who finds the holidays a grueling experience.

How Cissy Crew, Wonder of the World, Of Grapes and Nuts and Kvetch have been met with Ovation Recommendations, LA Times Critic's Choice, and more than a dozen other awards and nominations, prompting Stage Happenings to remark: "We wish SeaGlass would produce more often.  Once a year is not enough to see acting this vital."

We are thankful for the praise, and producing more often (in our own space) is just one of the many future goals we have set for ourselves.

That's where you come in.  We are grateful for any contribution to help us meet our budgeting goal this year.  We've set up several perks and premiums to inspire you.

With your help we will be able to continue to bring live theatre to Los Angeles.

Many thanks from your friends at SeaGlass Theatre.

story:
Overall Concept 

"[Richard is] determined to prove a villain" (I, i, 30)

An ensemble based exploration of the falseness in Shakespeare's portrayal of King Richard III.

Emphasis on Shakespeare's exaggeration of Richard's malevolence/deformity and the presence of/reasons behind the obvious bias towards the Tudor family.

Metatheatrical moments of humanity included periodically as Richard intermittently becomes conscious of the fact that through no fault or choice of his own his history and reputation are being rewritten and tarnished.

Technical elements

Non-naturalistic lighting/sound to highlight specific textual moments or to enhance moods/themes of the play.

Set/Stage

Sparse set in order to give emphasis on physical and emotional embodiment of text, themes, and symbolic resonance. 

Runway thrust stage set outdoors in the Trinity College Quad.

Costumes/Props

Costume fragments, historically accurate to time period. 

Props very occasional and only when neccessary, also historically accurate. 

Cast

Jane Smythe 

Kevin Wong

Marlow Stainfield

Arun Radhakrishnan

Samantha Finkelstein 

Hannah Wilkinson 

Angie Salomon 

Show Dates

October 3rd and 4th, 8:00pm

The Impact

With the money raised from this campaign, the following will be made possible:
- Hiring a professional stage combat director
- More elaborate lighting effects
- Higher quality props
- Longer practice window with stage weaponry

Other Ways You Can Help

- Spread the word about the campaign!

story:
My name is Romana Soutus and I have been working in the New York theatre scene for the past 2 years. I have been incredibly lucky enough to work at the incomparable La MaMa Experimental Theatre Club and have worked alongside such wonderful theatre companies like Yara Arts Group. The lessons I have learned from these New York institutions have shaped my way as an artist and I couldn't be more grateful.

Now, La MaMa Experimental Theatre Club and Yara Arts Group are taking a chance on me. La MaMa is producing my devised piece, "Murder Bar" at The Club this coming February 14th - 16th, 2014, and Yara Arts Group will be our financial sponsor by helping to make all donations tax-deductible.

The evening will be a Cabaret Extravaganza featuring murder ballads as performed by international musicians, a clown show as well as unexpected twists and turns throughout the night. The piece is an opportunity for the audience to, for a single evening, break down the walls we put up between ourselves and our mortality and instead find the humor, tragedy, pain and beauty that comes with society’s greatest fear. 

Grab a drink with Death and help us make this show come alive!

How Your Contribution Helps:

  • $60 will pay for copies of the script
  • $120 will help pay for a costume
  • $500 will help cover transportation for one artist
Please help fund what will be an unforgettable evening. Donations from individuals like you are the lifeblood of the arts and every little bit helps.

story:
The Innocent Never Forget To Breathe

OMAHA - In the spirit of rebuilding community, Jungle Productions would like to help others breathe. 

Jungle Productions announced it has selected Omaha as a pilot market for re-imagining performance arts, and will kick off the organization’s production schedule with the Nebraska premiere of Tim Barr’s Oxygen.

In accordance with Jungle Production's mission,  tickets will be  given  to area agencies allowing underprivileged youth and adults to attend Oxygen. Based on first hand experience, an opportunity to see art, hear live music, eat and watch a show can be life changing...AND it happens in one night.

Please help Jungle Productions change lives through your donation.

About The Show

The play, told through the eyes of an ailing-yet-spirited family patriarch (Paul, played by Barr), reflects on the toxic effects of vermiculite mining in Libby, MT - effects that left generations first incapacitated, then dead.

A longtime actor who has appeared in more than 170 productions, Barr learned about Libby, MT’s mining history while living and teaching in Missoula, MT in the late 90s. The show also features Omahans Lydia Bruckner as Young Jackie and Christopher Levering as Young Paul.

What sets Oxygen apart from most Omaha theatre ventures is Jungle Productions’ preshow event that includes food, live music and live visual arts in an intimate theatre setting designed to draw the audience, performers and art together. Further, Oxygen raises awareness of a larger issue:  asbestos poisoning in communities - a concern for Nebraskans, as well.

“This is truly a collaborative effort,” said Barr, “and Omaha offers a brilliant, receptive arts community excited about supporting a Nebraska premiere that tells an important story while showcasing other art and entertainment forms, as well.”

Barr, who interviewed dozens of Libby residents in order to create Oxygen’s composite character of Paul, noted the impact of asbestos from vermiculite mining began in Libby as early as 1919, and clean-up efforts continue today.

“Libby was infected with poison,” said Barr. “Children would swing on an asbestos-laden playground. Housewives would die because they did their husbands' laundry. Men would literally climb into barrels of asbestos. The tremolite dust stuck in their lungs and on their clothes.” For the Nebraska-based Barr, the interviews were both eye-opening and heart-wrenching.

“The story of the injustices by the W.R. Grace mine in Libby needed to be told. People are still dying as a result of asbestos exposure and tremolite-dust ingestion,” Barr said. "Grace also owned Western Minerals in Omaha. Asbestos related deaths and illnesses are expected to increase greatly by 2020."

“I wanted to help the community expose the mine for allowing asbestos-contaminated topsoil to cover the town’s playgrounds and for disregarding the long-term effects of asbestos exposure, for allowing deaths that could have been avoided had there been no negligence.”

Information: http://jungleproductions.wix.com/timbarrsoxygen and https://www.facebook.com/timbarrsjungleproductions 


Who's Who

Tim Barr

Tim Barr has participated in more than 170 productions in the US and abroad, and was named the 1998 Montana High School Speech and Debate Coach of the Year. His accomplishments include a host of roles at Nebraska’s Bellevue Little Theatre, Seattle’s Taproot Theatre, Book -It Theatre and Missoula Children’s Theatre. Tim also originated the role of Watson in the world premiere play The Shining. Tim has made countless appearances on stage, film and television in roles as writer, director, actor and producer.

Jungle Productions

A creative arts production company, Jungle Productions is responsible for bringing the Nebraska premiere of Tim Barr’s Oxygen to Omaha. Dedicated to promoting creative, collaborative arts projects, Jungle Productions marries theatre with food, music and visual entertainment to fashion intimate, relevant, first-of-their kind experiences designed to entertain, enliven and envelop communities.

story:
Woohoo! Thanks to Missoula's diverse community and continued interest in Irish Dancing, our troupe is growing! As a non-profit, we need your support to keep our dancers in the beautiful embroidered uniforms you're accustomed to seeing at our public events. 

This year we have eight dancers who are being promoted to 'Novice' level. We'll need a new skirt for each dancer, at a cost of approximately $300 each. 

Missoula Irish Dancers never charge admission to the many events performed at each year.  This year we have performed at schools, nursing homes, festivals, parades and other community events. The school is a non profit, supported by tuition fees and fund raisers. 

We appreciate your consideration of a donation to help keep our dancers in these beautiful costumes. 


What We Need

  • Eight new skirts at a cost of $300 each. 
  • The skirts remain property of the school and are handed down as new dancers advance.  This ensures that all dancers are able to perform without needing to invest in costumes

The Impact

  • Our mission is to preserve the Irish culture by way of teaching Irish step dancing to new generations of dancers.
  • The dance troupe performs publicly with no admission costs. This includes festivals as well as special community events, such as performing at nursing homes.  
  • We've been in the community for nine years, your donation will help future dancers feel confident in their performances and bring a celebratory spirit to festivals and community centers.
  • Irish dance is an excellent way for kids to stay active, make friends, and learn about the Irish culture while practicing an ancient art.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Follow us on Facebook to be the first to know of upcoming performances
  • Visit us or donate directly at www.MissoulaIrishDancers.com
  • Share our page with your friends and family!

   What We Need 
 
Eight new skirts at a cost of $300 each.  
 The skirts remain property of the school and are handed down as new dancers advance.  This ensures that all dancers are able to perform without needing to invest in costumes
 
  The Impact 
Our mission is to preserve the Irish culture by way of teaching Irish step dancing to new generations of dancers. The dance troupe performs publicly with no admission costs. This 
includes festivals as well as special community events, such as 
performing at nursing homes.   We've been in the community for nine years, your donation will help 
future dancers feel confident in their performances and bring a 
celebratory spirit to festivals and community centers.

Irish dance is an excellent way for kids to stay active, make friends, and learn about the Irish culture while practicing an ancient art.


  Other Ways You Can Help 
Follow us on Facebook to be the first to know of upcoming performances Visit us or donate directly at www.MissoulaIrishDancers.com

Share our page with your friends and family!

story:
RISK

It's 1966 and London is swinging like a new-spun noose... 

Frankie and Aggie know all about risk: Life in Kilburn’s gangland has seen to that. But now their Daddy’s sick and the Bold Boys across the river are causing ructions. There’s blood in the water and panic on the streets. Daddy’s kingdom is falling apart and the girls have nowhere to turn, nobody to help them-

But then, oh then Frankie comes up with The Plan.

Aggie comes onboard and all Hell breaks loose…

Two sisters. One city. And a criminal empire that could tear them both apart.

What We Need & What You Get

We're asking for some green (and blue, and pink, considering the colouring of the Euro) to cover: 

  • rehearsal space 
  • our legally contractual (and morally obligatory) insurance 
  • Our beautiful vintage-style costumes 
  • We'll also use this money to give every member of the team a small stipend, so that they have something to show for their work before the production goes up. 
If you help us with this, not only do you get the warm glow of having helped an unfunded company make something beautiful, you also get exclusive access to the creative process, crew and cast. You get to become part of our criminal little family, and you don't even have to shoot anyone. 
Isn't that awesome? 

Why Should You Fund Us? 

Whiskey Tango Foxtrot Theatre is a small, independent, currently unfunded company which has been making theatre for more than five years. 

RISK will be our most ambitious and innovative project to date and we're hoping to bring as many of you as possible on the journey with us. 

In a world where we seldom see women as protagonists onstage, in which we seldom see the Irish diaspora shown in a positive light and in which certain stories seem to be repeated ad nauseum, RISK wants to put two very different Irishwomen forward. We want to try something new. 

And we want you to help us. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help: 

  • You can make noise about the campaign. Share the videos, like them. Spread the word and have your friends do the same.  

  • Tell your mammy and everyone you know about us when you have them cornered, either in the pub or some other venue. (You know, when you're face to face.) Say lovely things about us, even if you don't mean them. Nobody will know. 

  •  Come along to see the show in September- We'll be delighted to have you. You'll also get to see what all the fuss was about. 

  • You can also use the indiegogo share tools, but tell your Mammy first.

story:
Don't Leave Us In The Dark

Dark Room Theatre Company is set to be a launching pad for up-and-coming theatre artists by offering a balance of creative freedom.  Within the framework of our upcoming season, we will provide a place for creative expression and artistic collaboration among numerous visual and performing arts diciplines.


Dark Room Theatre Company, a theatre incubator, is supporting the city of Greenville, SC by launching a new professional theatre venue in our growing community of the Pendleton Street Arts District.  Dark Room Theatre Company is becoming a vital fixture in this neighborhood by offering an affordable theatrical outlet for this burgeoning artistic destination.


Our Mission

Our mission is to inspire, amaze, empower, and educate artists and individuals in our community through our season of plays. We strive to develop shows that inform, challenge, and create dialogue. We will maintain our focus on cross-polinating like-minded artists through our unique concentration of staged readings and productions of new works, devised pieces, physical theatre, under-produced works, deconstructed and re-imagined classic works, and other unique shows.

Our Season

December 9-13  //  Specter by Don Nigro
January 29-31  //  Don't Tell Mama - Cabaret Showcase
February 11-14  //  Venus in Fur by David Ives
March 11-14  //  The Last Flapper by William Luce
April-June  //  Various One Acts -TBA
July 21-24  //  Gruesome Playground Injuries by Rajiv Joseph
October 13-17  //  Faust compiled by Missy Vaughan-Kleppel
November 17-21  //  Circle Mirror Transformation by Annie Baker
December 15-19  //  Tennessee Williams Piece - TBA
to get more detailed information about our season, please go to our website.

Where Your Contribution Goes

We are seeking donations to help us acquire basic theatrical equipment and supplies for our upcoming season. Your contributions will fuel the cultural renaissance in the Pendleton Street Arts District. 

The Breakdown:

  • Lighting - blubs, gels, clip lights, power strips, lighting props
  • Sound and Lighting Board - designed for our intimate spacemail
  • Curtains - custom fit to create a transformative black box inspired space
  • Rehearsal Cubes - cubes built for imaginative and minimalist set design
  • Costumes - basic costumes for our shows
  • Signage - to create more foot traffic and bring awareness
  • Royalties - to use certain plays, music, etc.
  • Office Equipment - copies, research, binders, business cards, etc.
  • Advertisement - photos & videos for PR, posters, playbills, etc.


    Expect to See and Do

    Dark Room Theatre Company is the only performing space in the Pendleton Street Arts District. Our community is crying out for cultivaton of economical theatre performances.  Dark Room is intimate space where the public can enjoy theatre, collaborative events, and be a co-working space tailored to the Arts District.


    The Team

      Shea Bahnsen // artistic director, co-founder, physical theatre teacher
      Missy Vaughan-Kleppel // co-founder, devised work playwright, director
      Stephen Boatright // director, photo & video, teacher, public relations
      Gil Snowden // resident playwright, actor, public relations
      Christin Davis // teacher, dancer, actor


      Location, Location, Location

      The Pendleton Street Arts District is a stones-throw from the bustling Downtown Greenville. With the expansion of Downtown, the city of Greenville is currently working on efforts to connect Pendleton Street to the buzz of energy on Main Street. Currently, through redevelopment authorities, many businesses and artists are making their home on Pendleton Street, adding to the economic impact of this neighborhood. Restaurants, a coffee shop, and multiple galleries and retail stores have begun to settle and gain popularity. Dark Room Theatre Company sees potential and growth in this area and can directly contribute towards the artistic expansion of the Pendleton Street Arts District. 


      Other Ways You Can Help

      Dark Room Theatre Company is eternally grateful for your contribution. If you are unable to assist us financially, we are always in need of volunteers. We are on the lookout for seamstresses, makeup artists, stage managers, graphic designers, website developers, and advertising/public relations connections.

      Please donate if you can and share our campaign with others.

      Thank You for your contribution to help us find out light.

story:
Who We Are

Hippie House Productions is a multi-medium art production house and community.

  • Founded in May 2014 with the purpose of bringing artists closer together and providing a highly accessible network where businesses and artists can communicate
  • This is our second production and our first fully independent production and we hope to use its assembly process to build a stronger community

Hippie House Productions is us. It's dozens of other people, too. And - it could be you.

What We Are Doing

We are raising money to help us crush the only two obstacles in our path towards completing this incredible project:

  • The procurement of performance rights to the show and general production value will be the two biggest expenditures
  • We seek only to raise as much as we need to meet the above requirements
  • If you help us reach our goal, we will happily demonstrate our gratitude by giving you extra access to both our show and the Hippie House network

Why We Are Doing It

We seek to conquer our financial obligations for this production while providing an avenue for growth as artists and as a community at large. We live in the present, and anticipate a bright future.

Challenges

We are an independent production company producing its first full-production. The first steps are always the most critical and we are focused on creating a solid infrastructure for collaboration.

  • We are dependent on public enthusiasm, we aim for our project to excite you as it does us.
  • With few resources at hand we must explore creative, economical solutions while focusing on giving back to our supporters.

How You Can Be A Part of the Experience

Become part of our community. With your support we can ensure your seat at the show as well as offer you different levels of access to the experience:

  • Reserve your seat and your contribution is donated to the show's production value .
  • Become a Patron- reserve your seat, and help HHP while recieving recognition for your support and presence within the community.
  • Sponsor our show- We can offer your business/company advertisement services during the production, reserved seats, and give you publicity within our network.
  • Use your voice- The most powerful tool we have is each other. You can pay it forward by sharing our campaign with friends. Let others know about exciting opportunities for noble causes.

Let's expand our sense of community. Let's 'dream big' together!

story:
Improv Camp Needs Your Help!

Improv Camp has earned its nickname of the Best Camp Ever because it provides young adults with a safe, positive environment where they can be themselves and learn from some of the best improvisers North America has to offer. Campers gain confidence and skills that apply not only to the stage, but to all aspects of everyday life. They also forge lasting friendships that span the country and last a lifetime. This strong community of improvisers allows Improv Camp to come back better every year.

The Improv Camp’s wonderful staff have donated thousands of dollars and willingly given much of their time and energy to this project because they believe so strongly in it. Improv Camp has NEVER intended to make a profit because it continues to spend every dollar on the best facility, trainers, food and activities for our campers. Every Improvcamper's experience is our top priority. 

The fact is we are using the same equipment we have been since we started out camp in 2001. Old equipment that needs to be repaired regardless of how much duct tape you put on it. We want to see the campers shine as brightly as they possibly can. In order for this to happen we need a new lighting system! One that will fit into the environmentally friendly theme of our home Camp Fircom. These new LED lights will be used for night time performances and fun activities that will make camp bigger and brighter than ever before. This is where you come in! THIS IS YOUR TIME TO SHINE! 

What We Need

We want our stage to live up to the outstanding work our campers do in our nightly performances.  We need $2,200 to purchase a new set of professional LED lights and a compatible control board. This equipment can see us through to the next decade of Improvcamp! That means that if 100 people donate just $22 each we will cover the entire cost of the new lights!

 What You Get

For your donation you will receive a video of thanks from Improvcamp, your name will be placed on our 2015 donors page at improvcamp.com and you will feel really happy the week of August 20th to 27th knowing that 140 kids are having the time of their lives.

We also have some great perks! 

  • $22 donations receive a special shout-out in our 2015 thank you video, filmed at Improv Camp!
  • $55 donations receive a VERY SPECIAL shout-out and a 2015 Improv Camp T-Shirt made by the amazing MEAGS FITZGERALD!
  • $100 donations receive a special shout-out, a t-shirt and lifetime high-five privileges from members of our 2015 Improv Camp staff!

Our Stretch Goals 

What happens if we exceed our goal? Check out our big plans below! 

AT $3000 - we can afford to purchase two new LED dance effects for our evening celebrations. For example, imagine the excitement a pair of REVO 4s could create on opening night! Or perhaps we could get this closing celebration started with the Dual Galaxian? 

AT $3500 - we can afford to install custom lighting bars at Camp Fircom making our lighting trees a thing of the past! 

AT $4000 - we will be able to invest in a set of our very own microphones and stands. Every year we rent these to make sure that our Talent show night is heard perfectly. 

AT $5000 - we will be able to to purchase a full sound system with mixer, two powered speakers and stands. Our technical needs for Improvcamp will be filled for the next decade saving us hundreds every year in rental costs. 

You Still Reading?

What can you do if you don't have any money to help us out? Take 5 minutes and do one of the following things:
  • Share the link to this fundraiser with everyone you know. Especially improvisers and Alumni Improvcampers. Twitter, Facebook and google plus are great ways to get the word out.
  • Email your parents and thank them for sending you to Improvcamp! 
Thanks everyone!

story:
What happens when four girls, living in a city that never stops for anyone, attempt to take an evening to answer the questions of existence that come with facing the end of time?

Sonia, Iris, Joana, Alessandra: we are four international actresses that have met in New York, probably will not be here for long, and want to explore what it means to be in one place, together, for a very limited amount of time, through an interactive theatrical project which will take place on the night of the 12th of August, at Jimmy's No. 43 in the East Village.

Some of the questions we are trying to answer are:

What is time for us? What kind of relationship do we have with time? When and how do we feel the passing of time? What does it mean to have a strong experience with time? Can we synthesize time into a simple explanation?

We hope to make this a moving and memorable experience for our community, and for all those who were directly or indirectly linked to the creation of this project. Being an entirely self-created and self-supported theatrical event, whatever you can give will make a critical difference in our success. Whatever you can afford to donate will help us create the event we have been working on with so much passion and dedication. Thank you in advance for your generosity, and thank you for your time...

And please, donate soon... time flies!

story:
Our Story

As multidisciplinary performers, Anne Goldberg and Martha Cargo strive to fuse their individual visions of groundbreaking art into an evening-length work encompassing the disciplines of dance, music, and visual art. Their unique backgrounds have brought them together, and The Field has named them Emerging Artists-in-Residence. To that end, Anne and Martha are seeking your support to help them pay the $550 course fee, which will enable them to attend regular workshops with visionary artists and work 6 hours of weekly rehearsal towards a final presentation at The Kitchen, long celebrated as a forum for interdisciplinary and progressive artistic projects in New York City.


The Impact

By helping Anne and Martha financially, they will be able to benefit from rehearsal space, production costs, professional feedback and support from members of The Field.  In their development of an evening length performance in the spring, they look forward to benefiting from Emerging Artist workshops with peers and masters in the field of dance and music.  The process of developing new work is an exhilarating process, though it can be daunting when faced with the costs of production and fees. 


What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $550 for our tuition, which includes the cost of the Emerging Artist workshop series and production costs at the Kitchen, as well as all rehearsal space.  Any money raised over the 550 will be well spent on costuming, artist fees, and any other money will be put aside to book a venue for a full evening length performance.


For our donors, we look to hold a short series of masterclasses and open rehearsals to show our progress.  We invite donors to take part in offering feedback on our project, and to participate in the creative process by attending our rehearsals on specified dates.  Finally, we wish to offer a masterclass open to all levels of experience, in which donors have the opportunity to work with Anne and Martha in an intimate, thought-provoking manner.


Other Ways You Can Help

Please share Anne and Martha's story with your friends and family to help spread the word!  Donations of any amount will be greatly appreciated, and will significantly boost both of Anne and Martha's careers.  By participating in the Field's residency, they will have many opportunities to share their work with top professionals in the industry and with the greater New York City community.

story:
Who We Are

“My advice to you: don’t just sit around waiting for other people to tell you it’s all right to have fun. Come on, Benny, we got to cut the nine o’clock cake!”- Holiday, Sez She

Shhh Productions is pleased to announce their return to the Edmonton Fringe Festival with another wild and crazy show, SEZ SHE. Written to be performed by at least five actresses, the sequel to Jane Martin’s last monologue play with be tackled by only a duo of actors who will be reveling in virtues of brevity that include hilarity, surprise and homespun philosophy. This collection of monologues roams the range of contemporary perspective on everything from sexual harassment to sleeping in theatres to the erotic appeals of silence.

The creators behind Shhh Productions, Lindsay Nelson and Sarah Wheeldon, began their journey at Grant MacEwan University in the early 2000s. After becoming good friends in swimming class -yes, swimming- they decided to start a company where they could produce shows at the Fringe about some of their many adventure travels. After the year 2004, Lindsay moved to Vancouver and Sarah to Calgary but they still managed to maintain their friendship and their mutual love for performing arts. AND SO, after a 9 year hiatus, they have overcome the challenges of 1000 KMs and the Rocky Mountain Range to collaborate on a project that is worthy of their efforts; encouraging creative collaboration across Western Canada.

What You Get For Donating

$5 a big thank you hug from us and your name in the program

$15 Your name in the program and A Sez She poster signed by the cast and crew

$25 All of the above plus a ticket to the show any night you choose

$50 All of the above plus your name or company logo on the poster and/or handbill (before print deadline), a personal thank you card and two tickets to the show

$100 All of the above with four tickets to the show any night you choose

$200+ All of the above with eight tickets to the show any night you choose

How You Can Help

Being a small company, Shhh Productions is funded solely through personal investment and private donations. The generosity of our supporters plays an integral role in the success of our shows and we are deeply grateful for their continued support. As you can imagine, living in different cities and putting together a show has its costs. Chiefly among these are the rights for the script, registration for the festival and print materials. We have tried to keep everything as simple as possible, but we are still in need of YOUR HELP through monetary and/or material donations (Paper, printing, costumes, etc). We have dreamed of reuniting creatively where it all began, at one of the worlds largest Fringe Festivals, the Edmonton Fringe. But we can't do it alone! If you share our passion for live theatre, we would appreciate any contribution, no matter how small. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't donate a couple dollars, please lend your support by spreading the word, or encouraging your Edmonton friends to come see the show.

Our sincerest thanks for your support and for promoting the Arts in Canada.
