story:
Producer(s) Bio

Samantha Demboski and Gary Stensland have been a part of the improv and sketch comedy scenes in Seattle for the past five years. They met at Gonzaga University, where Gary graduated with degrees in math and music composition, and Samantha studied theater and--while she didn't leave with the piece of paper--learned a lot about herself. Together, they form the production duo Who Dat Cindy and are two of the founding members of sketch and improv group Fifty Percent Less Bear. Separately, Gary recently appeared in the cabaret-drag-rock n' roll-monster-inspired-romp "The New Improvised Musical" at Jet City Improv and has been gigging around Seattle with his guitar and angelic voice for the past five years. Samantha is also a founding member of the sketch group BEEF!, the creator and producer of NASTY Improv, has previously performed in the karaoke-night-improv-spectacular Empty Orchestra at Jet City Improv, and is the creator/host of the podcast Here's What You Don't Do.

What Is This Darn Show, Anyway?

Fauku and Jeremy are two self-proclaimed "geniuses," who--despite lacking subtlety, teamwork, social skills, sincerity, mental stability, and any semblance of success--believe themselves to be burgeoning gods of performance art. It's only when a new enclave of fellow artists has them confronting their own dysfunctional motivations that they're forced to examine the lives they've chosen to lead.

Along with writing and directing, Samantha and Gary take on the roles of Fauku and Jeremy, describing them as "the worst versions of ourselves--but worse." This dig into the muddy well of mental health combined with the undefinable nature of performance art as a medium forms a narrative of six real people making highly unreal things with very real consequences.

Unlike most musicals, every song in This Is My Dinner is a performance given by the characters within it. As a result, each song is accompanied by the cast (guitar, keyboard, violin, triangle, trash-can, hitting stuff) and showcases their personal aesthetic as performers and artists. What they choose (and don't choose) to say and the style of the song says as much about the characters as it does about the narrative.

First performed as a twenty-five minute musical revue in 2016, a revised and expanded hour-long version of the show was produced at the Seattle Fringe Festival in 2017; this upcoming, full-length production in August at 12th Ave Arts in Seattle represents the culmination of years of writing and re-writing, self-examination as people and artists, and a whole lot of love for these severely messed up people in their messed up world.

You (We) Need What We (You) Have!

We (Samantha and Gary, hi) are asking for $2000 to help cover production costs for this show:

  • $800 - Performance space rental cost
  • $400 - Actor stipends
  • $300 - Rehearsal space rental cost
  • $300 - Marketing and promotion
  • $150 - IndieGoGo platform/credit card processing fees
  • $50 - One giant owl head

What do you get for your money? Options!

  • Tickets to the show! You can help us out now and still get your tickets in the process! Upon completion of the campaign, you'll receive an email with an individualized coupon code for your free tickets to be used on our online ticketing site or at the door!
  • Full show soundtrack! Can't make it to a performance? You can still enjoy the music! After the production wraps, we'll create a studio-recorded show album with the full cast, to be distributed via Bandcamp for streaming and download in September!
  • Po-ART-ry(!) Receive a personalized piece of ART from the show's stars, Fauku and Jeremy! Will it be a six page poem? A three line ballad? A drawing of the inside of your heart?? A broken dream??? Who knows!
  • Sculpt-ART-ure!(?) Four people can receive a mixed-media-sculptural "poster" used in the promotion of the show. Could it be an embellished stag head? A mosaic of broken dishware? Some elaborate papier mache? You'll see!

What Happens Next?

Hopefully by this point you're so in love with the show and the perks that you've already chosen how much you want to give! Get clicking on those buttons! And use those Indiegogo share tools to spread the word, and direct people to the Who Dat Cindy Facebook page for updates: https://www.facebook.com/WhoDatCindy/

This production will happen no matter what. It's too big and personal and important to us and straight up awesome for it not to be produced. However, your funding will help ensure that we don't tear our hair/wallets out in the process.

Thanks, and we hope to see you in August!

Sam/Gary//Fauku///Jeremy////ART

Thanks, and we hope to see you in August!
Sam/Gary//Fauku///Jeremy////ART

story:
Mission

My name is Adina Taubman. I am an actor, a playwright, a teacher, and a gun violence prevention activist.

There have been over 250 school shootings since the Columbine massacre in 1999. This is a national epidemic and our new normal.

Since the election of our new president, there has been an increase in bullying amongst young people, and with Betsy DeVos as our new Secretary of Education, it's possible that soon legislation will be introduced to allow guns in our schools.

It's more important than ever to keep our children safe.

I became a gun violence prevention activist shortly after Columbine.

When I had my first child in 2005, the need to help make our schools and communities safer became one of my top priorities. So, I began performing A Line In The Sand in high schools, with the goal of creating a dialogue for students about how they can create a more compassionate school community.

After more than 10 years of performing for students and listening to them talk about their experiences, I have experienced firsthand the unique power of theater  to create empathy and to inspire positive action. I have seen students make connections with each other and open their minds to new ways of thinking.

By contributing to this campaign, you will help five New York City high schools, who lack the funding to do so, bring A LINE IN THE SAND to their students. 

You will give these students the opportunity to begin to heal their school communities. 

You will give them the opportunity to learn how to write a play about their experiences and to learn basic performance skills, by participating in a 10 session writing and performance workshop that I offer.

Most importantly, you will help them to find their voice and share it with their classmates and teachers.

What I Need & What You Get

I need to raise $5,000 to bring A LINE IN THE SAND to five New York City high schools, which covers my $1,000 fee, per school, to perform the play, lead a post show discussion with the students, and teach the writing and performance workshop. 

My fee pays for rehearsal space, compensating my director and stage manager, and teaching the workshop.

The Impact

More than 5,000 students have seen A LINE IN THE SAND nationwide.

What educators are saying about A LINE IN THE SAND:

"Students engaged in wonderful conversations about their feelings and what they had seen."--Paula Schwartz, former Superintendent, Region School District #10, CT

"A LINE IN THE SAND made us all stop and think. We realized that we must pay attention. What happened at Columbine High School could happen anywhere."--Karissa Niehoff, former Principal, Lewis S. Mills High School, CT

"This play should be seen by as many young people as possible."--Richard Konet, former Principal, Parsippany Hills High School, NJ

Thank you

Thank you in advance for your support. And please remember a donation of $10 or $20 goes a long way to show these students that we value them.

Sincerely,

Adina Taubman
Writer/Performer of A LINE IN THE SAND

story:
Who are you?

Hey! My name is Kristin Wagner and I am a passionate Boston-based dance performer, choreographer, educator, and administrator. Simply put, I want to support art.  I want to make dance happen. More importantly, I want to advocate for female dancers and choreographers. As a young female artist, I am always dedicated to supporting young female dancers and choreographers, and have continuously been drawn to creative projects that focus on the female experience.

Wait a second...this campaign is already fully funded...

You are absolutely correct!  I am incredibly humbled and so ridiculously excited to say that in just under two weeks, we met our campaign goal of $3700.  THANK YOU, THANK YOU, THANK YOU to everyone who has contributed!  Being that we are a group of ambitious, driven boss-ladies, we thought, "why stop there?"  And so... we have officially unofficially set a STRETCH GOAL of $5000.  Our initial goal of $3700 covers all production costs associated with this project, all of which you can read about in the original campaign description below.  These funds do not support the dance makers and dance performers involved in this project.  I am now hoping to raise an additional $1300 as a base stipend for the choreographers showcasing work in this show.  Often the last paycheck cut, dancers are notoriously underpaid for their work.  The average dancer and choreographer works for as little as $0.50/hour.  In a world where women are already paid less than their worth on average, I think we should do everything we can to pay these artists an adequate stipend.  It is extremely important to me to demonstrate the value of these dance artists as fully as I can, and I hope you will help me to do so.  To learn more about this project, please continue to read our original campaign description below, and please consider making a contribution to this production.  You will be supporting a dedicated group of female dance artists, as well as joining a movement standing up for the voices of women in the arts, and women in the world at large.

---

What is "...that's what she said"?

“…that’s what she said” will be a theater production focused on the concept of womanhood. My goal is to showcase work from emerging and established female choreographers in the Boston area that speak to the female experience in today’s world.

Cool! What does "...that's what she said" need?

“that’s what she said” will be produced at The Dance Complex for a two-night run, March 30-31, 2018.  I am seeking financial assistance in the amount of $3700 to cover all production costs associated with this show, so that I may pay the artists involved in the show using ticket sales, and maybe buy myself a glass of wine after the show.

How did I come up with $3700?  Glad you asked!  Here is the breakdown of expenses, based on industry averages in the Boston area:

The bulk of the money associated with producing this show goes toward renting space and paying artists who make this show possible from a technical standpoint, such as running lights that bring the dance works to life or creating eye-catching promotional material that bring in an audience.  Here is a clearer look at who would be benefitting from your contribution:

If you are interested in a more specific look at our budget, and who it will benefit, please feel free to check out this link here: ­­­­­­­­_______________________________

I’m down with that! Speaking of paying hard-working artists, will the dancers get paid?

You bet! I will be working tirelessly to make sure that the dancers and choreographers of "...that's what she said” will be paid. Each participating choreographer will be paid a percentage of box office revenue, after production costs have been covered.  

IF we: Cover all production costs with this campaign (see the bar graph above) and sell out each performance night…

THEN: Each choreographer gets about $130 a performance, or $260 if they perform in both shows.

We currently have the following choreographers' participation confirmed (click the links to see some of them movin' and groovin'):

  • I.J. Chan
  • Audrey MacLean
  • DeAnna Pellecchia/KAIROS Dance Theater
  • Sarah Thorne
  • Aysha Upchurch
  • Vanessa White/The Lipstick Criminals
  • Me!

Ok, I’m up to date about the money. Why is “… that’s what she said” so important? Why should I invest in this?

Simply put, this project makes dance happen, and will make dance happen after this show is complete. Dance can inspire perspective. Dance can tell a story. Dance can inspire discussion.

  • This show will address womanhood, something that (despite the media focus of late) is still never discussed, appreciated, or acknowledged enough.
  • This show offers the female perspective from diverse female lenses.
  • This show could resonate with the audience, and inspire discussion. It could even inspire in someone (or many people) the dedication to change and action.
  • Female dancers and choreographers receive fewer opportunities than their male counterparts. I’d like to change that.
  • The show will foster a community of female artists who support and nurture each other in the pursuit to create high quality art, examining the female experience. #girlpower, am I right?
  • The more people that see our show, and support our cause, the more we multiply our community of support for female choreographers and dancers AND the need to hear the female voice and perspective in art.
  • I will be providing, free, to choreographers:
  • Promotional material (videography and photography), which supports artists in the future with their own funding, education or grant endeavors
  • and development opportunities

This support will help the artists involved continue to produce more art, and in even better form than before.

Vincent van Gogh once said, “What is done in love is well done.” I am doing this from a place of deep, deep love, and I will do everything I can do it well.

I’m feeling inspired… but pretty broke. How can I still help?

I totally get it! Promising projects are popping up all over the place, and though I constantly want to support everything, sometimes my bank account just says "NO!"  If you are feeling motivated or inspired to help, but are lacking the financial means to do so, please know that I will greatly appreciate any contributions, big or small, tangible or intangible, including but not limited to:

  • Spread the word! Do you have a rich uncle? An art-enthusiast cousin? Let them know what I am planning, and see if they want to get involved!
  • Share resources! Have an idea of other groups, communities, or organizations that are like-minded and might be interested in partnering up in some way, shape or form?  Let me know! I am very interested in building a larger network of cool people who like dance.
  • Send me some love! Sometimes, a hug is all I need.
  • Stay connected! Keep us in the back of your mind as the show comes near; get a group of friends together and come see us do the damn thang!  Don't worry - if money is still a little tight, I plan on releasing a whole bunch of ways to save on tickets.  Follow us on Instagram and Facebook (@followwhatshesaid), or check our website regularly (http://kristincwagner.com/thats-what-she-said.html).

Thank you for your consideration, and no matter what you choose to contribute (if anything), I hope to see you at a show, a gallery, a dance class, or a concert sometime soon.

 Warmly, Kristin

Who are you?Hey! My name is Kristin Wagner and I am a passionate Boston-based dance performer, choreographer, educator, and administrator. Simply put, I want to support art.  I want to make dance happen. More importantly, I want to advocate for female dancers and choreographers. As a young female artist, I am always dedicated to supporting young female dancers and choreographers, and have continuously been drawn to creative projects that focus on the female experience.Wait a second...this campaign is already fully funded...You are absolutely correct!  I am incredibly humbled and so ridiculously excited to say that in just under two weeks, we met our campaign goal of $3700.  THANK YOU, THANK YOU, THANK YOU to everyone who has contributed!  Being that we are a group of ambitious, driven boss-ladies, we thought, "why stop there?"  And so... we have officially unofficially set a STRETCH GOAL of $5000.  Our initial goal of $3700 covers all production costs associated with this project, all of which you can read about in the original campaign description below.  These funds do not support the dance makers and dance performers involved in this project.  I am now hoping to raise an additional $1300 as a base stipend for the choreographers showcasing work in this show.  Often the last paycheck cut, dancers are notoriously underpaid for their work.  The average dancer and choreographer works for as little as $0.50/hour.  In a world where women are already paid less than their worth on average, I think we should do everything we can to pay these artists an adequate stipend.  It is extremely important to me to demonstrate the value of these dance artists as fully as I can, and I hope you will help me to do so.  To learn more about this project, please continue to read our original campaign description below, and please consider making a contribution to this production.  You will be supporting a dedicated group of female dance artists, as well as joining a movement standing up for the voices of women in the arts, and women in the world at large.---What is "...that's what she said"?“…that’s what she said” will be a theater production focused on the concept of womanhood. My goal is to showcase work from emerging and established female choreographers in the Boston area that speak to the female experience in today’s world.
Cool! What does "...that's what she said" need? 
“that’s what she said” will be produced at The Dance Complex for a two-night run, March 30-31, 2018.  I am seeking financial assistance in the amount of $3700 to cover all production costs associated with this show, so that I may pay the artists involved in the show using ticket sales, and maybe buy myself a glass of wine after the show.How did I come up with $3700?  Glad you asked!  Here is the breakdown of expenses, based on industry averages in the Boston area:The bulk of the money associated with producing this show goes toward renting space and paying artists who make this show possible from a technical standpoint, such as running lights that bring the dance works to life or creating eye-catching promotional material that bring in an audience.  Here is a clearer look at who would be benefitting from your contribution:If you are interested in a more specific look at our budget, and who it will benefit, please feel free to check out this link here: ­­­­­­­­_______________________________I’m down with that! Speaking of paying hard-working artists, will the dancers get paid?You bet! I will be working tirelessly to make sure that the dancers and choreographers of "...that's what she said” will be paid. Each participating choreographer will be paid a percentage of box office revenue, after production costs have been covered.  IF we: Cover all production costs with this campaign (see the bar graph above) and sell out each performance night…THEN: Each choreographer gets about $130 a performance, or $260 if they perform in both shows.We currently have the following choreographers' participation confirmed (click the links to see some of them movin' and groovin'):
I.J. Chan
Audrey MacLean
DeAnna Pellecchia/KAIROS Dance Theater
Sarah Thorne
Aysha Upchurch
Vanessa White/The Lipstick Criminals
Me!

Ok, I’m up to date about the money. Why is “… that’s what she said” so important? Why should I invest in this?
Simply put, this project makes dance happen, and will make dance happen after this show is complete. Dance can inspire perspective. Dance can tell a story. Dance can inspire discussion.
This show will address womanhood, something that (despite the media focus of late) is still never discussed, appreciated, or acknowledged enough.
This show offers the female perspective from diverse female lenses.
This show could resonate with the audience, and inspire discussion. It could even inspire in someone (or many people) the dedication to change and action.
Female dancers and choreographers receive fewer opportunities than their male counterparts. I’d like to change that.
The show will foster a community of female artists who support and nurture each other in the pursuit to create high quality art, examining the female experience. #girlpower, am I right?
The more people that see our show, and support our cause, the more we multiply our community of support for female choreographers and dancers AND the need to hear the female voice and perspective in art.
I will be providing, free, to choreographers:


Promotional material (videography and photography), which supports artists in the future with their own funding, education or grant endeavors
and development opportunities
This support will help the artists involved continue to produce more art, and in even better form than before.Vincent van Gogh once said, “What is done in love is well done.” I am doing this from a place of deep, deep love, and I will do everything I can do it well. I’m feeling inspired… but pretty broke. How can I still help?I totally get it! Promising projects are popping up all over the place, and though I constantly want to support everything, sometimes my bank account just says "NO!"  If you are feeling motivated or inspired to help, but are lacking the financial means to do so, please know that I will greatly appreciate any contributions, big or small, tangible or intangible, including but not limited to:
Spread the word! Do you have a rich uncle? An art-enthusiast cousin? Let them know what I am planning, and see if they want to get involved!
Share resources! Have an idea of other groups, communities, or organizations that are like-minded and might be interested in partnering up in some way, shape or form?  Let me know! I am very interested in building a larger network of cool people who like dance.
Send me some love! Sometimes, a hug is all I need.
Stay connected! Keep us in the back of your mind as the show comes near; get a group of friends together and come see us do the damn thang!  Don't worry - if money is still a little tight, I plan on releasing a whole bunch of ways to save on tickets.  Follow us on Instagram and Facebook (@followwhatshesaid), or check our website regularly (http://kristincwagner.com/thats-what-she-said.html).
Thank you for your consideration, and no matter what you choose to contribute (if anything), I hope to see you at a show, a gallery, a dance class, or a concert sometime soon. Warmly, Kristin

story:
"Besides, aren't these things supposed to be a whole big fancy spectrum? There are the girls who are like, “Yeah, I’d go gay for Ellen or Beyoncé,” and there are the girls who are like, “I would not even go gay for Ellen or Beyoncé,” and there are the girls who are like, “I will only sleep with Ellen or Beyoncé even if George Clooney is available.” And they all exist on this long line of gay, straight, or middle, but most girls would probably go or stay gay for Ellen or Beyoncé, given the opportunity..."

MAYBE I'M NOT READING THIS MAP CORRECTLY is a new play about a group of high school girls learning how to deal with homework, boys, parents, climate change, the patriarchy, and possibly having more-than-platonic feelings for your best friend even though you're not even really sure if you're gay.


Our production is lead by a super-rad all-female creative team including award-winning playwright Elyse Pitock, director Clare Mahoney, and producer Allison Ciuci. We are thrilled to be showcasing new work by women and providing opportunities for female theatre artists on and off stage. This piece is being developed with Dixon Place, a non-profit institution dedicated to presenting multi-disciplinary original work and to inspiring creativity and risk-taking for all New York artists.

If you share our passion for awesome new plays, supporting women in theatre, or if you're just curious about Ellen and Beyoncé sexuality spectrum, we kindly ask you to consider donating to our production. Your generosity will go towards our set and props, costumes, and rehearsal space, as well as our marketing and fundraising efforts. If we exceed our minimum budget, all donations will go towards stipends for our amazing cast and creative team. 

We are so grateful for any support you're able to provide for our play. There are some fun little perks on the side bar for you to peruse, but gifts of any size are welcome and deeply appreciated.

Dixon Place, February 10th, 7:30PM. Hope to see you there.

story:
Hi! We're Leigh, Dan, and Charlotte, those creators of Begochiddy you know and love. We're a trifecta of awesome, or at least that's what we sure our moms would call us. We are setting out to create four new works this year, from now (go!) until 2016's end. Our new works always have PUPPETS, ORIGINAL MUSIC, and tell stories about the past transformed into the future. You'll just have to come to our shows to know what this means, first hand! With your contribution, you will have a partial or full season-pass to our new works, a veritable year-long arts festival for your personal enjoyment and edification.
We wish to bring you works-in-progress readings that are full of vibrant beauty, heart-filled realness and surprising vulnerability. We're calling these shows "Play Reading Plus", which means a show with music, puppets, staging but made available for your viewing while still new, developing and fresh!

For your contribution of $35, you'll receive a Partial Season Pass with entrance to one of our new show readings, of your choosing!

For your contribution of $60, you will receive a Season Pass with entrance to two new shows, of your choosing!

And for your contribution of $120, you will have a multi-season with entrance to all four shows!

For your contribution of $200, you will receive a multi-season pass and one other person, along with an artisinal shadow-puppet-in-a-jar. It is so worth it!

For your contribution of $500, you will receive a multi-season pass for you and one other person, along with an artisinal shadow-puppet-in-a-jar AND a song written for you and recorded by Charlotte Moroz. This is one of the best ideas you've ever had!

For your contribution of $12,000, you will receive a multi-season pass, along with a family burial plot in the heart of the hippest Brooklyn cemetery (*cremation available for scattering). Run, don't walk!

Why have we started this campaign?
Leigh, Dan, and I are passionate about creating new work, in a world that needs, frankly, new ideas, new hopefulness, new struggles with the meaning of life, new ways of telling our old stories. Leigh is a director, a vision-keeper, a nurturer of ideas and works with Lincoln Center and the creatively bombastic children's theater genius company, Trusty Sidekick. Dan is a stage manager of colossal proportions, working primarily with Punchdrunk's Sleep No More, a dramaturg, a logistician, an equal visionary. He kicks butt and coordinates the impossible. Charlotte is a puppet-maker (working with the majestic Puppet Kitchen) , a music-maker, a writer, a performer, a clown and improviser. Charlotte brings fresh show ideas and baby scripts to Dan and Leigh, and they all wade through the unknown and new together. This trifecta of awesome so wants to bring the maximum new show potential to you this year. This means producing 4 shows on modest/excitingly low budgets, one every 3 months!

Has anyone ELSE promised you front-row seats to FOUR new shows this year? Don't bother thinking about that, just rest your mouse over the button "Fund this project" and we'll show you to your proverbial gold-gilded seats. What kind of shows?, you ask. Rightfully so. These are original music-filled, homemade puppet-filled, ancient-meets-present-meets-future story-filled shows. They will not be obnoxious, they will not lie to you, and they will, dare we say it, have light and life to offer, as well as questions, many questions. 

WHAT DOES YOUR CONTRIBUTION FUND?

Our funding will go to:
4 shows produced. The funds will go to: paying our performers fair and market wages, renting a beautiful performance space, PR, and building materials.

Your contribution guarantees you a seat to see these new works, either a season or multi-season pass. What a deal! We are committed to making beautiful and truthful new live theater, the kind that makes you think how cool it is to be a human being. By funding this project, you are saying YES to independent, real and flawed human beings. YES to nurturing the creative independence and vision of young artists. YES to good music, music that doesn't sound like a robot wrote it. YES to original stories.

CHALLENGES
We wish to convey our sincerity to you via our choosing a project and goal that is a stretch for us and yet very attainable. This is not a safe goal to go after, per say, because we want to grow and expand through this experience. Anyone who makes theater knows that we are setting out on a very modest budget to develop 4 shows, but we want to give you something special, something heartfelt, and we want to give you as much as possible this year. This means making FOUR NEW SHOWS for you this year, a goal that allows us to make things with quality and love and also with frequency. Producing one new show every 3 months will be a big feat to pull off, but we have reservations with a performance space for each show date, and a team around us to keep us on schedule.

HOW TO HELP?
While contribution is of course a wonderful way to build this new theater endeavor with us, there are so many other ways you can join in the fun. We are so grateful to you for getting the word out, for emailing friends, colleagues, and family, and for all your good vibes, juju, and encouragement. If purchasing tickets presents any hardship for you, please be in touch. We'll help you to the max!

Thank you so much for your loving support! We'll see you at the first show!

story:
CREATING SPACE - OUR SPACE TO CREATE

As Palestinians living in Israel, we face systematic and institutionalised discrimination on a daily basis. Our freedom of expression is denied. Racist incitement and hate crime is on the rise. Our identity, history and culture are being erased.

We at Khashabi Ensemble Theatre want to challenge this status quo. We are a group of young Palestinian theatre professionals and artists who are committed to building up an independent theatre and artistic space in the city of Haifa. A place where our thriving community of Palestinian artists can be free to create, experiment and perform.

This new theatre and arts space will be located in the Wadi Salib area of downtown Haifa, a neighborhood where the majority of Palestinian residents were forcibly expelled in 1948 and which until today is the target of ongoing Judaisation.

HERE’S THE DEAL

The first stage of this project consists of renovating and preparing the space. It has not been functional for the past 10 years and therefore needs a serious overhaul. We need to raise a total of 50,000 USD to complete this work…

Once the renovation work is completed, the next stage of our project will consist of equipping the building, turning it into a functioning artistic space. The Khashabi Ensemble Theatre will include a small theatre hall, seating an audience of 80 people, as well as spaces for workshops, exhibitions and other arts.

A NEW ARTISTIC MOVEMENT

After the expulsion of the Palestinian inhabitants from Wadi Salib in 1948, the Palestinian character of the neighbourhood has gradually been eradicated by Israeli authorities. Overtaken by governmental and office buildings, today little more than a memory remains of its history.

Establishing a Palestinian arts space in this neighbourhood therefore forms a vital part of our aim to revive and recreate Palestinian identity. We will work closely with our community to develop unique artistic projects, empower young Palestinians through artistic workshops, and develop unique methods to engage new audiences to enjoy and be inspired by the arts.

Our theatre aims to develop a novel artistic ideology in the Palestinian community, based on the ideals of cooperation, experimentation and mutual support. But this growing artistic community that we are part of is desperately in need of a space.

WE NEED YOUR HELP!

We are calling on all friends of free creation and Palestinian culture to make a donation - large or small - in order to help us build up our space. We also need your support in spreading the campaign to a wide audience, by sharing it on social media (using the share buttons above), and by telling your friends and family about it.  

We thank you all for supporting us on our journey!

Let’s make it happen!

story:
Support Periapsis Music and Dance's 2015 Season!

As we enter our third season, we're continuing our commitment to create and produce collaborative performances at the highest level.  Since last year we've expanded our creative team, focused our mission, and renewed our energy towards our goals.

We have some great performances coming up this winter and spring, with repertoire both new and returning:

  • February 7-8 performance on the Peridance Faculty Showcase
  • February 15 joint show with Resonance Collective at ShapeShifter Lab
  • February 22 performance lab at Steps on Broadway
  • Our spring season, June 12-13, at Kumble Theater

The February performances will feature a new ensemble work by choreographer Hannah Weber and composer Jonathan Howard Katz, and the June shows will be a full evening Periapsis event, with:

  • A new ensemble piece by choreographer Erin Dillon and composer Jonathan Howard Katz;
  • Guest choreographer Bradley Shelver and composer Tonia Ko, in their joint work we commissioned;
  • An expanded version of Hannah Weber's winter piece;
  • Three movements around Bach, a showcase of solos for our three choreographers;
  • And more!

Perks

We've got some great donation perks to show our appreciation and thank you for your support, including some that are only available through this campaign!  These include an invite to our Periapsis Party at Spectrum on February 24 (rescheduled from January 27) for just $25, where you can meet our artists and chat over great food and drink, enjoy some small performances, and even bid in a silent auction.  For a $150 donation, Periapsis artists will create a short, personalized improvised performance that you'll be able to view online.  And for $250, we're proud to be able to offer prints of beautiful artwork of our performers by Laurie Fraser Manifold.


Making it happen

From the beginning, we've been focused on running our organization in a way that respects our artists and allows for institutional growth.  We were quick to obtain our 501(c)(3) status, we run a payroll for our dancers, we document our performances so that they're useful not just for Periapsis but for our artists and guests as well.  This Indiegogo campaign will fund a significant part of our 2014-2015 budget, and your donation will go towards:

  • Artist pay.  This is our top cost, as it should be.  We pay our dancers and musicians for rehearsals and performances and have increased our rates significantly over the past seasons.
  • Venue rental.  This includes rehearsal studios and performance halls.
  • Video, audio, and photos.  We do our own video editing to cut costs and tailor the edits to the choreographers' preferences, but the documentation itself is an expense.
  • Administrative costs.  This would include insurance, accounting and payroll, some staffing hours.  These costs are very modest but are still a portion of our budget.
  • Publicity and marketing.  Flyers, posters, website, advertising, etc.  Also a modest cost.

Thank you!  And please share!

story:
That's me!

I am Manuel Kisters(18) and a cologne based dancer and choreographer.

When I was 14 years old a serious injury, a girl, my love for music, movement and arts led me to dance.  Since then i have been trained by international and local dancers. 

My interest in choreography first came up when I saw Alvin Aileys "Revelations" back in 2011 .That day I decided that one day I will start creating dancepieces to be able to share the joy of dance!

I am very glad to have chosen this journey, because now I am working on my first evening filling dance performance. And its so much fun!

That's the project!

My project is about the Body-Mind problem, thus it deals with the question whether a soul exists. This is a broad topic so I narrowed it down to  one of the 2 major theories about this problem. The theory I'm basing my work on is "Dualism". Being first brought to awareness by Platon two-thousand years ago and rephrased by René Descarts in the 17th century,the theory of dualism says that the human consists of two beings: The body and the mind/soul

I am exploring the relationship between them by comparing the theory with my own experiences. Questions such as: "What is the body and what is the Mind/soul?" "What kind of reliationship do they actually have and how does it influence us?" "How does the mind function?" are the fundamental base of my work.

What I need...and what you get! 

Basically, I'm 1100€ short of financing my dream.

All the money you spend will cover the costs of:
  • the rehearsal space rental
  • performance space rental
  • stage setting( THE BOX)
  • costumes
  • lighting

All of the involved artists and people work for free. Indiegogo is my only source of financial income, next to selling the tickets. Obviously, if we manage to raise more than 1100€, the remaining money will go towards the artists involved!

For eveything you give, I will give you something back. Check out the perks on the right side to see what you can get.


The Impact!

I will hopefully perform this piece at the schrittmacher festival in Aachen in March. I am also planning on performing this piece in England, but there is no set date yet! 

After this project I will continue creating and prepare myself for choreography festivals in Summer 2015. I will also apply for dance universities in europe, to study dance/ choreography and improve my skills as a dancer and choreographer.

You cannot donate? Don't sweat it!

Being an artist I know that sometimes money is missing  for whatever reason.

There are some other ways of supporting me: 

Spread the word! Thats always a great help.Share it with Friends, Family, and social media maybe they want to donate and/or come to the performance themselves.

And last but not least, come to the performance yourself! 

Barnes Crossing - BO ND ING BODYANDMIND - Performance details

Facebookevent - BO ND ING

Facebook - Manuel Kisters

That's me! I am Manuel Kisters(18) and a cologne based dancer and choreographer.
When I was 14 years old a serious injury, a girl, my love for music, movement and arts led me to dance.  Since then i have been trained by international and local dancers. 
My interest in choreography first came up when I saw Alvin Aileys "Revelations" back in 2011 .That day I decided that one day I will start creating dancepieces to be able to share the joy of dance!
I am very glad to have chosen this journey, because now I am working on my first evening filling dance performance. And its so much fun!
That's the project!
My project is about the Body-Mind problem, thus it deals with the question whether a soul exists. This is a broad topic so I narrowed it down to  one of the 2 major theories about this problem. The theory I'm basing my work on is "Dualism". Being first brought to awareness by Platon two-thousand years ago and rephrased by René Descarts in the 17th century,the theory of dualism says that the human consists of two beings: The body and the mind/soul
I am exploring the relationship between them by comparing the theory with my own experiences. Questions such as: "What is the body and what is the Mind/soul?" "What kind of reliationship do they actually have and how does it influence us?" "How does the mind function?" are the fundamental base of my work.
What I need...and what you get! 
Basically, I'm 1100€ short of financing my dream.All the money you spend will cover the costs of:
the rehearsal space rental
performance space rental
stage setting( THE BOX)

costumes

lighting
All of the involved artists and people work for free. Indiegogo is my only source of financial income, next to selling the tickets. Obviously, if we manage to raise more than 1100€, the remaining money will go towards the artists involved!For eveything you give, I will give you something back. Check out the perks on the right side to see what you can get. 
    The Impact!
I will hopefully perform this piece at the schrittmacher festival in Aachen in March. I am also planning on performing this piece in England, but there is no set date yet! 

After this project I will continue creating and prepare myself for choreography festivals in Summer 2015. I will also apply for dance universities in europe, to study dance/ choreography and improve my skills as a dancer and choreographer.

There are some other ways of supporting me: 
Spread the word! Thats always a great help.Share it with Friends, Family, and social media maybe they want to donate and/or come to the performance themselves.
And last but not least, come to the performance yourself!

story:
OK. Brooklyn Arts Council will award Shakedown Dance Collective a grant of $1700 to take-over the NYC Transit Museum on April 1, 2015 at 6:30pm (no fooling). Buuuut, that's not enough to complete the thing. Help us reach $1000 and we'll totally force people to watch us tell stories and shake body parts. ANY donation made here will support the cost of rehearsal space, costumes, props and an honorarium for performers.

SHAKEDOWN WHO?

The Shakedown is a dance collective daring people of all shapes, ages and experience levels to defy their couches and find freedom in an expressive, dance and performance practice. Learn more (AND JOIN) at shakedowndance.com.

THE PERFORMANCE

People from all walks of life will perform choreography based on real transit moments collected from the general public- including but not limited to:

  • #ManSpreading
  • Public Drunkenness
  • Mobile Make-Up Application
  • Pushing, Pulling, Sleeping
  • Gross Things on the Ground
The performances will happen on the platform and in the historic subway cars of the NYC Transit Museum (once the Court Street subway stop in downtown Brooklyn).

REASONS TO PART WITH YOUR MONEY

  1. You believe dance is for the people.
  2. Our goal is so small, $25 makes you a high-roller.
  3. Wish fulfillment. This is paid performance "gig".
  4. We're bad-asses (MTA shut down our guerrilla subway performance last year)

BUT WAIT, THERE'S MORE
We can DEFINITELY go plenty past $1000. The more we raise, the more people get paid, the more cool costumes, props, and rehearsal space we get to craft this art for you. Thanks!

CONTACT

Shakedown Co-Founder: Jamie Benson / getdown@shakedowndance.com

story:
Each year CACN highlights issues that the Association of Chinese Americans at UCLA feels is important to the Chinese-Americans and Asian Americans on campus as well as our surrounding community. This year marks the 25th anniversary of CACN from its first curtain call in 1989 and since then we have emphasized topics such as the homicide of Vincent Chen during the 1980s (Catalyst, 2012) and the history behind Chinese immigrants on Angel Island (Angel Island, 2013).

This year, our story revolves around a traditional, single father who grapples with the generational gap between himself and his three children. It explores a struggle that many can relate to: the dichotomy between tradition versus modern Asian American ideals and how families come together to embrace one another's dreams. 

In addition to the drama portion of our production, CACN is also a showcase of various performances such as:

  • ACA Lion Dance
  • ACA Hip Hop
  • Traditional Dance (Chinese Cultural Dance Club, CCDC) 
  • Martial Arts (UCLA Kung Fu, UCLA Wushu)
  • Musical Student Performances

A Message from the Producers

Dear Community Member,
Thank you for allowing us the chance to share our annual Culture Night experience with you. Each year, the seats of Royce Hall are filled by undergraduate and graduate students, UCLA alumni, faculty, family members, and community leaders drawn from Westwood, West Los Angeles, Chinatown, and San Gabriel Valley. This year, we present the story of a single-parent father and his three children as they experience the strengths and restrictions of family. Through our exploration of generational disconnects, we aim to encourage dialogue about prominent issues affecting Asian Americans. We are making great strides to complete our production but we need your help.
As the university suffers from insufficient funding for outreach and cultural programs, it has become increasingly necessary for us to call upon the assistance of our community and those who support education through the arts. The annual cost of this production nears $30,000, making funding a necessary priority in our planning. Limited financial resources will prevent us from reaching our goals in the production of this show, but the support of our community will ensure our success. 
If you decide to become a supporter of our culture night, you will be showing over 1,800 audience members your support for the Asian American community. Furthermore, our show is the product of a year’s worth of incredible work put forth by students at various levels of involvement: production, acting, and cultural performance. Your support will help over 150 students discover the importance of community involvement and the empowerment, self-confidence, and joy such an experience brings.
Please help us reach our goals in educating a greater audience on issues that directly impact the Asian American community on and beyond the UCLA campus. On behalf of our student organization, we would like to express our gratitude and appreciation for your support.
Thank you very much for your time and consideration.
Sincerely,
Alan Chen & Peter Wang
Producers, CACN 2014

Our production costs nearly $30,000 and if we reach our Indiegogo goal it will help us cover over 10% of it! We are working hard to fundraise and find sponsors, but ultimately we need help from community members like you. Your contribution and support will go towards funding one of ACA's largest and biggest traditions, but where does all this funding go? To break it down your help will go towards: 

  • Renting out the prestigious venue of Royce Hall
  • Sets and props materials
  • Advertisement materials (i.e. Program booklets, flyers, posters)

If you can contribute even just $1 to our production, we truly appreciate your support! But if not, you can still support us in other ways like:

  • sharing our Indiegogo to your friends, family, Facebook etc.
  • checking out our fundraising events if you're near UCLA
  • attending our show on Saturday May 10th, 2014 (tickets are FREE for UCLA students at the Central Ticket Office and if you are a community member you can email cacn2014@gmail.com)

If you or your business are interested in contributing $500 or more please contact our Sponsorship Chair, Jessica Wong at jwong693@ucla.edu, to discuss further details and review our official sponsorship packet.


Thank you for your time and ACA's Horse Staff of 2013-2014 appreciates every bit of support from you!

story:
The Short Version

The American High School Theatre Festival recognizes high school drama programs across the United States for their impact in their local community to educate and entertain an audience towards change in the world.

  • University High School is a Laboratory High School serving the College of Education at Illinois State University.
  • Our International Thespian Troupe (Troupe #1156) has been nominated, reviewed, and asked to perform at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe.
  • As a group, 15 from our theater program and our director will be taking Welcome to the Moon and Other Plays by John Patrick Shanley to the festival to represent our school, community, and the Midwest at the World's Largest Arts Festival

Our bags will be packed, set will be made, and we are excited to see our students as they embark on this one-in-a-lifetime journey. But, we need your help to get us there.

What We Need & What You Get

Our Indiegogo Fundraising will:

  • Purchase the Supplies for our Performance-in-the-round (PIR) marley flooring. Cut into the shape of a moon, painted and fireproofed for UK restrictions, this flooring acts as the central playing space for the collection of plays. This will later be donated to our school's speech team for their future PIR shows.
  • Assist with the cost of royalties, costumes, and props. If you have not read the plays, there are some surreal props. Click here for information.
The Cost of the trip per student is $6100 (before our at home fundraising) and any additional fundraising beyond our crowd-funded goal will go back into the trip assistance budget. 

The Impact

This experience not only broadens our student's performing talents and abilities, it provides our students with the following:

  • Each student joins an international community of performers, artists, and global ambassadors.
  • Each student gains leadership and mentorship opportunities at the Fringe.
  • Everything learned is brought home after the festival so that these students can share their experience as the leaders and mentors for the next school year.


    Other Ways You Can Help

    Please think of this project as we get things off-of-the-ground in preparation for travel. For many of our students, this is their first time traveling outside of the country.

story:
The Deal

We are the 2014-2015 Co-Chairs of Northwestern's Freshman Urban Program (FUP). FUP is a six-day pre-orientation program that introduces over 80 incoming Northwestern students to the diverse neighborhoods of Chicago where they learn about social justice issues, navigate the city, meet new friends, and open their minds to new perspectives. 

One of the program's highlights is what we call "Arts Night." We bring together performers from both Northwestern and Chicago for a night of creativity, social awareness, and entertainment. Now we've decided that it would make for an even cooler experience if Arts Night was open to the entire student body.

Over the years, we've developed a great relationship with Young Chicago Authors (YCA), the non-profit that sponsors the largest spoken word competition in the world: Louder Than A Bomb. Founded in Chicago in 2001, the event attracts 1000 participants from 120 schools in over 100 different Chicagoland zip codes and 10,000 plus audience members. YCA will contribute their performance expertise if we can raise the funds to do so; Kevin Coval will emcee the event and bring with him a diverse group of Chicago artists including bands, graffiti artists, comedy troupes, slam poets, and more.

We believe that Northwestern, despite its locality, lacks a large-scale event that showcases the immense talent and passion located just a few miles south of its campus. We're hoping to change that. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need $3,000 to cover all booking costs and entry for the event
  • Your donation will make the event free and accessible to all students at NU
  • If we don't reach our goal, :(, the funds will be used for a smaller scale Arts Night.

The Impact

  • Expose Northwestern students to a small part of the immense Chicago art scene
  • Illuminate the crossroads of art, social justice, politics and community building
  • Start conversations!

story:
Short Summary

Initiated by Reginald Edmund, Black Lives, Black Words is comprised of ten minute staged readings from ten black playwrights in the city of Chicago, USA. The ten minute play series will be tied in with a shared project to be done in London, England to explore the black diaspora experience(s) in some of the largest multicultural cities in the world, Chicago, Minneapolis, Cleveland, Baltimore, and London. Both cities have had countless reports in the media, all negative, from police brutality to black on black violence but what are the views and other issues most prevalent to those who understand, live and work in the community? 

This project will give a voice to some of the most contemporary political black writers from both the US and the UK, asking them to explore the question 'Do black lives matter today?' Each will write a ten to fifteen minute play to address the political, economical and cultural as well as the social and academic issues related to the black experiences of the 21st century. This project will serve as a comparative study to raise awareness of the shared and different transatlantic experiences in the black community and evaluate the impact it has had on the black community at large.We are interested in plays that will not only discuss these important issues but also seek to provide solutions to the many problems that our community is struggling with.

Black Lives, Black Words event in Chicago will take place on July 29th at the Greenhouse Theatre alongside a panel discussion with the London event in the Fall being put together by Simeilia Hodge-Dallaway, Artistic Director of Artistic Directors of the Future, with the support of Theatre Royal Stratford East. 

Chicago based Theatre Companies signed on to be involved include MPAACT, Pegasus Theatre, eta Creative Arts Foundation, Black Ensemble Theatre and Congo Square.

Featuring works from playwrights: David Barr III, Shepsu Aakhu, Regina Taylor, Marsha Estell, Gloria Bond Clunie, Nambi E Kelley, Reginald Edmund, Kristiana Rae Colón, Carla Stillwell, James T. Alfred, Loy Webb, Elana Elyce, and more.

By pledging you become part of our precious team to make this important piece of work.

We want you to join the movement. Join us and be a part of cultural impact of this conversation and help create a better future for Black people in America. For all people. Right now.

What We Need & What You Get

  • This show can create change; by taking voices of black artists and giving them the power to say something beautiful and positive, we're opening discussions from varied black playwright experiences.This project is entirely voluntary. This is a bare-bones project and so we need help raising funds for marketing and promotion. Anything that you can give will be greatly appreciated.

  • The funds will help:

    • With promotional and marketing materials... i.e. postcards, and posters
    • Rent a rehearsal space for casts unable to secure space
    • Aid in securing a website for this event and allow all scripts contributed by the writers to be free to the greater community
    • Publish the book Black Lives, Black Words which will include all scripts

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Share this campaign page as much as you can. We want to spread the word and get the conversation going, and the only way to do that is through you guys. Thanks so much! Below are some ideas:

    • Share the campaign page on your Facebook wall and send it to all your friends!
    • Share the project on Twitter with the hashtag #blklivesblkwrd. 
    • Emailing close friends, family, news outlets, blogs, celebrities and rich people about it.

story:
Realizing A Dream

Hello all! Thank you for visiting my campaign page. This page exists because it has been a long time dream of mine to direct a stage production, and I thought what better senior project than doing something I've dreamed of and supporting our local high school theatre?

A bit about me:

For those who don't know me, I'm a 17 year old about to go into my senior year of high school. I have been in theatre more or less all of my life, and ever since playing Scrooge in A Christmas Carol in seventh grade I have wanted to try directing. 

Some of the roles I have played in local theatre include:

  • Ebenezer Scrooge, A Christmas Carol, Sunfied Waldorf School
  • Mr. Tackleton, Cricket on the Hearth, Sunfield Waldorf School
  • Arthur, Arthur's Stone, Merlin's Fire, OCEAN Program
  • Romeo, Romeo and Juliet, OCEAN Program
  • D'artagnan, Three Musketeers, Port Townsend High School
  • Audrey 2, Little Shop of Horrors, Port Townsend High School
  • Sound Design, The Nerd, Port Townsend High School
  • Stage Crew, Cinderella, Key City Public Theatre


Why Support This Project?

It creates local theatre. As I say in the above video, there are few opportunities for teens to take leadership roles in theatre in this town. This will help create them.

This could pave the way for student directors at PTHS in the future. This is an opportunity that currently does not exist in Port Townsend.

All proceeds after production costs will be donated to the PTHS drama club. These funds will be used to help maintain and improve our theatre, making it better for all future generations of teen actors. Possible purchases include replacing burnt out house lights, new curtains, new black paint for the stage, and a new sound system. 

Logistics

Proposed Budget:

  • $700 Royalties ($100 per performance)
  • $500 Set/Props
  • $500 Costumes
  • $200 Publicity (Printing posters/programs)
  • $600 Misc. (Repairs, unforeseen costs, etc)
Our Team So Far:

  • Noah Phillips - Producer/Director
  • Alvia Brass - Stage Manager
  • Libby Urner Wennstrom - Costume Design
  • Mazzie Peters - Lighting Design
  • J.r. Kienle - Sound Design
It takes a community to put on a show. If you want to be involved, feel free to send me a message here by clicking contact near the top of the page. We'll be casting the show in September, and gaining crew members as we go. Stay tuned for updates!
Performance dates will likely be three weekends in November, with exact dates TBD.
Thanks again for visiting the page! Anything helps!
story_txt:
Realizing A DreamHello all! Thank you for visiting my campaign page. This page exists because it has been a long time dream of mine to direct a stage production, and I thought what better senior project than doing something I've dreamed of and supporting our local high school theatre?A bit about me:For those who don't know me, I'm a 17 year old about to go into my senior year of high school. I have been in theatre more or less all of my life, and ever since playing Scrooge in A Christmas Carol in seventh grade I have wanted to try directing. Some of the roles I have played in local theatre include:

Ebenezer Scrooge, A Christmas Carol, Sunfied Waldorf School

Mr. Tackleton, Cricket on the Hearth, Sunfield Waldorf School
Arthur, Arthur's Stone, Merlin's Fire, OCEAN Program
Romeo, Romeo and Juliet, OCEAN Program
D'artagnan, Three Musketeers, Port Townsend High School
Audrey 2, Little Shop of Horrors, Port Townsend High School
Sound Design, The Nerd, Port Townsend High School
Stage Crew, Cinderella, Key City Public Theatre
Why Support This Project?It creates local theatre. As I say in the above video, there are few opportunities for teens to take leadership roles in theatre in this town. This will help create them.This could pave the way for student directors at PTHS in the future. This is an opportunity that currently does not exist in Port Townsend.All proceeds after production costs will be donated to the PTHS drama club. These funds will be used to help maintain and improve our theatre, making it better for all future generations of teen actors. Possible purchases include replacing burnt out house lights, new curtains, new black paint for the stage, and a new sound system. LogisticsProposed Budget:

$700 Royalties ($100 per performance)


$500 Set/Props


$500 Costumes


$200 Publicity (Printing posters/programs)


$600 Misc. (Repairs, unforeseen costs, etc)

Our Team So Far:



Noah Phillips - Producer/Director

Alvia Brass - Stage Manager
Libby Urner Wennstrom - Costume Design
Mazzie Peters - Lighting Design
J.r. Kienle - Sound Design
It takes a community to put on a show. If you want to be involved, feel free to send me a message here by clicking contact near the top of the page. We'll be casting the show in September, and gaining crew members as we go. Stay tuned for updates!
Performance dates will likely be three weekends in November, with exact dates TBD.


Thanks again for visiting the page! Anything helps!

story:
HELP FUEL THE FIRE

For four years the Fire This Time Festival has been providing early-career playwrights of African-American descent the opportunity to have their voices heard and their creative visions realized. Since our first season, the Fire This Time Festival has sold out every performance and has proved to be a festival of extreme talent. We are proud to have played a part in the careers of many new playwrights and actors who can now be seen on Broadway, television and full-staged productions in many theaters around the world. The Fire This Time Festival has quickly become a destination for diverse audiences, producers, and artists seeking exciting possibilities and opportunities in contemporary drama.

THE FIRE CONTINUES: SEASON 5

Our fifth season begins in January 2014. Our core program will be a full production of short plays, running over two weeks. We will introduce new work from:  

Angelica Cheri, Lori Parquet, Jonathan Payne, Erika Rose, Judy Tate, Joshua Wilder

And featuring a production of Camille Darby's full length play "Lord's Resistance" directed by Christopher Burris. 

In addition to our core program, several playwrights from prior seasons will return with staged readings of full-length works.  A panel discussion hosted by Indie Theatre Now's Martin Denton and director Nicole Watson are also a part of our annual event, as well as an open mic night hosted by Dominique Morisseau.

KEEP THE FIRE BURNING - $5,000 in 45 days.

The Fire This Time Festival is committed to keeping ticket prices low and quality of work high. This year we have 6 playwrights with over 50 actors, stage crew, lighting, sound and administrative costs. Ticket prices are able to cover the Horse Trade Theatre costs, but we still need your help. We rely strictly on your donations to cover all other costs. Your donations extend beyond stipends; they extend beyond rentals; your donations are an investment in the careers of new playwrights and continue the uprising of an art movement. Your donations last more than a season. They last a lifetime. 

$5,000 will close our gap for the season.  This $5,000 will go directly to the artistic expenses for the program, giving us the means to actually compensate our roster of talented actors, directors and other collaborators. 

The Festival has reached a very exciting moment.  Many of our playwrights, directors and actors are enjoying new and exciting professional opportunities. There has never been more demand for what we do.  And we want to do more! 

Help us keep the fire burning by making a donation today!

HOW THE FIRE STARTED

The first season of the festival brought together over 30 performers, directors, and other collaborators to create an amazing evening of short one-act plays. Presented by Horse Trade Theater Group over a sold-out run in February 2010. The Festival has evolved into an annual event, expanding upon its core short play presentations to offer panel discussions, staged readings, and other programs.

 To date, the Fire This Time Festival has produced new work by the following playwrights: Dennis A. Allen II, Jesse Cameron Alick, Deborah Asiimwe, France-Luce Benson, Jocelyn Bioh, Radha Blank, Christine Jean Chambers, Camille Darby,  Danielle Davenport, Kevin R. Free, Marcus Gardley, Kelley Nicole Girod, Katori Hall, Jason Holtham, Tracey Conyer Lee, Eric Lockley, Ione Lloyd, Zoey Martinson, Yusef Miller, Derek Lee McPhatter, Dominique Morisseau, Antoinette Nwandu, Jerome Parker,  Cynthis Robinson, Germono Toussaint, Pia Wilson, and Nathan Yungerberg. 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Even if you can't make a contribution there are many ways to help. Tell your friends about our campaign.  Join our mailing list, or inquire about volunteer opportunities.  We want to hear from you! www.firethistimefestival.com

story:
Thank you for taking a moment to consider my campaign. If you are receiving this directly from me, you already know who I am. If it has been forwarded to you by one of my amazing friends or family members, let me introduce myself. My name is Greg Campbell, and I'm attempting to raise funds to help me achieve my life-long dream. For those who are inclined to become a part of my adventure, in whatever way, on whatever level, I thank you from the bottom of my heart. Financial support will get me that much closer to accomplishing my goal, but good old moral support is also welcome and appreciated. 


While this may come as a surprise to many of you, some are already aware of my upcoming plan to leave my beloved Austin. What you may not know is the reason for my departure.

In a little over two months, Maggie, Rudy, and I (Maggie and Rudy are my sweet pups) will head to the Big Apple, where I’ve dreamt of living for as long as I can remember. Even before visiting, I knew it was the place for me. After my first time there, I was completely sold. I’ve been back several times since, and each time, I felt as if I were home.

Why New York City, you ask? Without question, the theater. From the first time I performed on a stage at Swift Elementary, I’ve been in love with acting. Since then, I’ve taken classes and performed on a somewhat irregular basis. This is when all that changes. I’m ready to pursue this dream wholeheartedly. In addition to acting, I also hope to publish and perform some of my own writing. In the past several years, I’ve begun to develop stories that I’d like to see produced on stage. I am committed to jumping in, buckling down, and giving all I have to pursue this dream of earning my keep as an actor/writer.

I’ve been very encouraged by the gentle nudging of friends and, in the past couple years, a few students (I teach ESL) who have managed to rekindle this dream. 

I turn 50 this year, and after doing a little research into “older” adults breaking in to this industry, I came upon the story of Kathryn Joosten. While you may not recognize the name, I’m sure you’d know her face. She packed up and moved to Los Angeles from Florida at the age of 55 to begin acting in television. She became quite well known as a character actress in sitcoms and a few dramas, most notably “The West Wing” and “Desperate Housewives.” Her story was just the spark I needed. George Eliot was right: “You’re never too old to be what you might’ve been.” Some sources quote it as “It’s never too late to be what you might've been.” In either case, the message has really struck a chord in me. The time is now!

Of course, breaking into this industry is not as simple as just moving to New York. I anticipate a tough, but I hope not incredibly long, road of daily auditions, searching for an agent, writing, and rewriting. If I could spend my first 6-12 months completely focused on this, I could really build a strong network within the theater community. Having a strong network is one of the most important aspects of establishing a theatrical career. Of course, younger folks have quite a bit more time to build on this. I’d like to concentrate my efforts, and really become a part of the theater community and my new city. In addition to pursuing my own dream, I plan to offer some of my time as a tutor to students who might otherwise not have the means to pursue theirs. I really want to play a meaningful part in my new home. 

This is where you can help. While I’ve managed to put away some money in preparation for the move, I’ve come to realize that I need a bit more upfront to get settled in. The rental market in the New York City area is pretty hot right now, and current residents with higher incomes than I’ll have upon arriving are obviously more attractive to landlords. The one thing that would give me an advantage would be the ability to pay for the lease upfront. I’ve been looking primarily in Brooklyn, Queens, and the Bronx (Manhattan is out of the question), and I’ve regularly found pet-friendly apartments for between $750 and $1000 a month (less than I had anticipated). 

I always think of the story Carol Burnett tells of the anonymous donor who helped make it possible for her to pursue her dream. I'm asking for your help, and, eventually, I’d like to be like that donor and help others in any way I can. I’m a big believer in “paying it forward.”


Here’s how I’d like to spend my time during the first 6-12 months:

Concentrated networking

Acting / Playwriting Classes & Workshops

Auditioning for no-pay / low-pay parts / student & indie films

Cementing involvement in community

Donating tutoring / college prep time to lower-income schools / students

Daytime commitments (auditions)(agent search)(tutoring)

Evening / Weekend commitments (writing)(tutoring)


And here's what I need the money for:

$9,000 - $24,000 [one to two year lease paid in advance]

$1,500 - $3,000 acting / play writing classes [honing skills / networking]

$225 - $750 head shots

$4,500 - $13,500 [12 to 18 months monthly expenses]


I’m very excited and a little nervous about this new adventure, and I hope you’ll be a part of it. Take a look at the perks I’m offering in exchange for your donation. I hope you see something you like. Thanks so much for your support!

See you at the Tonys!

story:
*PLEASE NOTE that all donations are in USD (US Dollars).                                                           *SVP NOTEZ que tous les montants des dons sont en USD (dollar américain)

DANSE À LA CARTE

Please support us in our mission to create and sustain consistent quality drop in classes and coaching in Ballet & Contemporary dance for the Montreal dance community. Danse à la Carte will be providing these classes in order to support the continued pursuit of professional and educational development and excellence in the Montreal dance community.

Faites un don et soutenez notre mission! Danse à la carte est un organisme à but non-lucratif qui offre des classes de ballet et de contemporain de qualité à la communauté de la danse montréalaise. Ces classes sont données de façon régulière dans le but de soutenir la poursuite du développement professionnel et éducatif de l’excellence en danse.


(version française un peu plus bas)


Mission statement


Over the past few years I have had the great pleasure of being able to work with many wonderful artists from a plethora of Montreal dance companies. Teaching regular drop in ballet classes in the city has made me a witness to the benefits and effects of providing these dancers with a neutral environment that is void of company politics and pressures. Current, future and retired Ballet dancers, Contemporary dancers and Modern dancers and teachers all taking a Ballet class or Contemporary workshop together, inspiring each other, supporting each other, networking, training and exploring new things together. Everyone is there because they want to take a quality class, to learn something new and to train hard in their chosen craft or passion. The dancers from this Montreal dance community deserve to have this space available to them when they need it. It is an invaluable tool in their training when classes are not provided for them, they are in between contracts, looking for employment, coming back from an injury or simply feeling defeated in their present employment.
It is my priority when I am teaching and in charge of a project that I provide an energetic enviroment based on support, respect, encouragment and space for self expression and exploration. I am very demanding as a teacher but I push people in a positive and productive way and my return is that I get to see people flourish. I want the montreal dance community to have a place where everyone is free to network, connect with other artists, refuel, grow, develop and hopefully find new inspiration.
In the classes and workshops presented to the community over the past 6 months I have had dancers from 

La La La Human Steps
Nederlands Danse Theater
La Compagnie Marie Chouinard
Rubberbandance Group
BJM Danse
Flak
Ezdanza 
Virginie Brunelle Danse Contemporaine
Cas Public

Het national Ballet
Le Royal Winnipeg Ballet
Atlantique Ballet Théâtre du Canada
L’École Supérieure de Ballet du Québec
Ballet Métropolitain de Montréal
Ballet Ouest de Montréal
Les Grands Ballets Canadiens de Montréal

I am committed to facilitating access to quality professional level classes for the dancers of Montreal and I hope that you may join and support me in this new venture. Given the very sudden and imminent closure of Ballet Professionnel Montreal (classes ending February 28th) I ask for your help  in creating a start up fund for this project so that I can continue to offer a minimum of 3 ballet classes per week which will be taught by experienced teachers who have a deep understanding of both classical and contemporary dance. Also in the plans are to offer 1 contemporary class per week as well as a professional level workshops exploring repertoire and methods of choreographers such as Nacho Duato, Victor Quijada, Barak Marshall, Andrew Skeels and hopefully Crystal Pite, Peter Chu and others.

I have a goal of raising $2500 to cover a portion of the costs of the first month of classes & workshops (teachers fees,studio rentals, ballet barres, supplies and administration fees) after which point the organization should be able to find it's footing and continue forward based on its own revenue. During this time myself and my team will be looking into registering as an official not for profit organization which will become the vessel for offering this opportunity for the continued professional development for all artists of the Montreal dance community. The city has become a mecca for dance not only in North America but well beyond yet we do not have 'infrastructure' to support it with consistency. I hope to be able to be able to create and sustain a space which is worthy of our hard won reputation.

In my view having access to proper training options is imperative for a healthy and successful career. Given the typically low salaries of dance artists keeping the cost of attending the classes is a priority and it is my goal to keep the price for training classes between $10 and $15 as well as the workshops between $20 and $40.

Sincerely,

Lisa Davies et l'équipe de Danse à la Carte, Veronique Giasson & Robin Mathes

(version française)

Mission de l'organisme

Au cours des dernières années, j'ai eu l'immense privilège de travailler avec de merveilleux artistes venant de diverses compagnies de danse montréalaises. Enseigner des classes de ballet ici sous une base régulière m'a permis de constater à quel point il est bénéfique pour un danseur de s'entraîner dans un environnement neutre, sans compétition ni politique de compagnie. 

Qu'ils soient danseurs classiques et contemporains, danseurs de la relève, danseurs retraités ou encore enseignants, tous peuvent bénéficier de classes quotidiennes et d'ateliers de danse contemporaine. En s'entraînant ensemble, ils peuvent s'inspirer de l'un et de l'autre, se soutenir, agrandir leur réseautage et approfondir leur technique dans un climat professionnel de haut niveau.

Un entraînement quotidien et rigoureux est essentiel pour les danseurs pigistes, car ceux-ci se retrouvent souvent dans des situations nécessitant l'existence de classes d'entraînement régulières: intervalles entre deux contrats, recherche d'emploi, retour au travail suite à une blessure, etc. Ces danseurs méritent de disposer d'un espace lorsqu'ils en ont besoin.

En tant que responsable du projet «Danse à la carte», ma priorité est de fournir un environnement énergique basé sur le soutien, le respect et l'encouragement, dans un espace où l'expression de soi et l'exploration sont mises de l'avant. 

Au cours des six derniers mois, j'ai enseigné des classes à de nombreux artistes pigistes, en plus de danseurs venant de diverses compagnies et écoles:

- La la la human steps

- Netherlands Dance Theater

- Compagnie Marie Chouinard

- RUBBERBANDance Group

- BJM danse

- Flak

- ezdanza

- Cas Public

- Virginie Brunelle danse

- Het national Ballet

- Royal Winnipeg Ballet

- Ballet-théâtre atlantique du Canada

- L'École supérieure de ballet du Québec

- Ballet métropolitain de Montréal

- Ballet Ouest 

- Les Grands ballets canadiens de Montréal

Pour l'instant, les cours offerts par «Danse à la carte» seront donnés dans des studios situés à proximité du centre-ville ou du Plateau Mont-Royal. 

Dans un futur rapproché, j'espère offrir une classe de danse contemporaine par semaine ainsi que des ateliers qui permettront d'explorer le répertoire et les méthodes de chorégraphes renommés tels que Nacho Duato, Victor Quijada et Barak Marshall. J'aimerais également pouvoir inviter Andrew Skeels, Crystal Pite et Peter Chu et plusieurs autres artistes que je respecte grandement.  

Je m'engage aujourd'hui à faciliter l'accès aux cours professionnels à Montréal et j'ose espérer que vous puissiez m'appuyer et me soutenir dans cette nouvelle aventure. Compte tenu de la fermeture imminente de Ballet Professionnel Montréal (classes se terminant le 28 février prochain), j'aimerais en quelque sorte prendre la relève et continuer d'offrir des classes d'entraînement sous une base régulière.

Maintenir l'accès à des classes adaptées aux besoins de la communauté professionnelle de la danse est une action indispensable à la réussite du milieu. En raison des faibles revenus de la plupart des danseurs, je tenterai de maintenir le coût d'une classe entre 10$ et 15$ et le coût d'un atelier entre 20$ et 40$. 

Je me tourne donc vers vous pour amasser les 2 500$ qui sont nécessaires pour démarrer le projet. Cet argent permettra de couvrir les frais du premier mois, soit le mois de mars. Je pourrai ainsi continuer à offrir un minimum de trois classes de ballet par semaine. L'organisation devrait ensuite pouvoir être autonome financièrement.

Nature des dépenses:

- salaire des enseignants

- location des studios

- barres de ballet

- autres fournitures 

Mon équipe et moi entreprenons déjà toutes les démarches afin d'enregistrer «Danse à la carte» comme organisme à but non-lucratif. Montréal est aujourd'hui un lieu important pour la danse en Amérique du Nord et partout à travers le monde. C'est pourquoi il est de notre devoir de continuer à nourrir le milieu. 

Nous n'avons pas encore nos propres studios, mais nous comptons être en mesure de créer et de maintenir un espace digne de notre réputation et de notre travail acharné.

Je vous remercie à l'avance de l'attention que vous porterez à mon projet.

Au plaisir de vous voir bientôt,

Lisa Davies et l'équipe de Danse à la Carte, Véronique Giasson et Robin Mathes
