story:
We are a grass-roots, family-driven, educator-supported initiative working to bring child-centered care and nature-based education to young children in the greater Monadnock area of New Hampshire.

In December 2020, when the much-loved Monadnock Waldorf School announced they were closing after 44 years, our community felt the collective heartache over the loss of programming dedicated to enhancing the spirit of our preschool-age children as well the magic of the school property at Old Walpole Road. 

By March, enough parents, caregivers, and educators had come together to recognize a collective vision and need to create something for our children. By May, an angel donor stepped forward with a gift generous enough for a down payment on the property. 

Fully informed of the inherent challenges of opening a Preschool in six months against the backdrop of the pandemic, with our children in our minds and hearts, we knew we had to try. 

In just the initial four months, parents and caregivers have stepped forward to offer their own expertise with everything from grant writing to creating our website, from formulating the curriculum to designing our logo and branding. Another family lovingly filmed and edited our promotional video while other community members, many through pro-bono coaching services at Hannah Grimes Center for Entrepreneurship, have provided counsel for our business plan, legal matters, and offered expert PR and Marketing advice. We have established a non-profit board and secured a fiscal sponsor through Sophia’s Hearth Family Center to accept tax deductible donations. Families have already volunteered time and hands to help us prepare the building for the opening of school. This is truly a community effort.

And now, here we stand, OUR VISION - Spring Hill Children's Center

Spring Hill operates under the vision that an early childhood education program is a central piece of its mission. Waldorf-inspired and nature-based classes for young children will operate on the campus. By recognizing the potential of the facility and the land, Spring Hill will harness the power of collaboration to facilitate additional programming with community partners. All programming offered at Spring Hill is consistent with the mission and is steeped in nature, love, rhythm, and community while honoring the individual spirit of each child.

 

We also have some very big news! We are excited to announce that Spring Hill has just acquired the property that will welcome the many children, families, educators, and animals that will be there daily!

Located on Old Walpole Road at the tip of Keene, NH, Spring Hill will be settled on the very property that housed the original Waldorf Early Childhood campus for almost 30 years. 11.5 acres of woods, meadows, streams, sandboxes, and indoor classrooms are happily waiting!

That brings us to now - we are stepping into our season of start-up fundraising and your financial support really matters. With these much needed donations, we will fund our initial start-up costs. The money raised through this site will go directly towards staffing, supplies, utilities, necessary maintenance to the property among many other general start-up fees. We are hoping that any extra money raised can then go towards scholarship funds to offer assistance to many families in need.  

Please consider donating today, for the hearts and minds of our young children.

 

What We Need

Our goal on this site is to reach $15,000. These donations will go directly to our initial startup fees - staffing, building maintenance, and classroom supplies being top priority.  

But that does not mean we cannot go higher! Our actual startup needs are closer to $35,000. We also know that many families in the Monadnock region are in desperate need of childcare and we would love to make Spring Hill accessible to everyone. The more money we can raise the the closer we can get to reaching that goal. We believe that all children should have to opportunity to be able to learn, love, and grow in nature.  

Where do the funds go if we do not reach our goal? Every single bit counts while we work to get Spring Hill off the ground for our Fall 2021 opening. Even if we do not meet our $15,000 goal, all donations raised will still be put towards our general start-up fees. 

That being said, we are so incredibly grateful to everyone who is here for us in many different ways. We would love to honor your generosity by putting your name among the trees, grass, rocks, and gardens where the children will be playing at Spring Hill.

The Impact

Our program, and therefore each child, is seen as a vital part of our greater community.  As a non-profit center, we seek collaborative partnerships with local organizations, individuals, and programs that share in our vision while bringing our families and community together.

By donating to Spring Hill, you will help enrich the lives of young children between the ages three to six in the Monadnock region by instilling a love of nature, curiosity, and lasting friendships. This will be a place where young children will be celebrated for who they are and build confidence in a supportive and caring environment. 

Your contribution will help build this much-needed nature-based school in a time where our lives are so heavily influenced by the electronic world. Spring Hill is an opportunity for children to explore the natural world together, developing the intersocial skills much needed to make humanity flourish while learning to respect the world we live in.

You will be helping us build an environment and program that will help small minds grow and thrive. 

We understand that not everyone is in the position to donate but there are many other ways to help us with our efforts!

Please consider helping us to spread the word through word of mouth, social media, emails, and phone calls! - Indiegogo has created "share tools" which make sharing our page simple and easy.

Visit our website - www.springhillmonadnock.org

or our Facebook page - Spring Hill Children's Center

Lastly, if you are in the area and would like to be a part of Spring Hill please do not hesitate to reach out. Every heart and hand is welcome.

Thank you
story_txt:
We are a grass-roots, family-driven, educator-supported initiative working to bring child-centered care and nature-based education to young children in the greater Monadnock area of New Hampshire.
In December 2020, when the much-loved Monadnock Waldorf School announced they were closing after 44 years, our community felt the collective heartache over the loss of programming dedicated to enhancing the spirit of our preschool-age children as well the magic of the school property at Old Walpole Road. 
By March, enough parents, caregivers, and educators had come together to recognize a collective vision and need to create something for our children. By May, an angel donor stepped forward with a gift generous enough for a down payment on the property. 
Fully informed of the inherent challenges of opening a Preschool in six months against the backdrop of the pandemic, with our children in our minds and hearts, we knew we had to try. 
In just the initial four months, parents and caregivers have stepped forward to offer their own expertise with everything from grant writing to creating our website, from formulating the curriculum to designing our logo and branding. Another family lovingly filmed and edited our promotional video while other community members, many through pro-bono coaching services at Hannah Grimes Center for Entrepreneurship, have provided counsel for our business plan, legal matters, and offered expert PR and Marketing advice. We have established a non-profit board and secured a fiscal sponsor through Sophia’s Hearth Family Center to accept tax deductible donations. Families have already volunteered time and hands to help us prepare the building for the opening of school. This is truly a community effort.

story:
"Reading is empowering. In fact it's one of the most empowering things a child can do. It gives them knowledge, confidence, hope, inspiration...It gives them access to the whole world. A world they might not otherwise have access to..."

 

Help children have access to that freedom, that superpower, by supporting our Summer Reading Program! :)

 

SUMMARY

Welcome to our Summer Reading Program brought to you by The Adventures of a Rogue Swan!

This summer we are running a Summer Reading Program to help children fall in love with reading. Every summer students fall a bit behind in their reading and this year is especially difficult as so many students have fallen behind because of the Coronavirus pandemic and many don't have the means to catch up. This program is free to anyone who wants to participate. Parents and kids set their own goals and at the end of the summer everyone gets prizes for their participation.

Children and their parents select their goals, the number and type of books they’d like to read and work with them to help them one-on-one to achieve their goals. So no matter their age or stage, the child is able to create attainable and achievable goals and reach them. This helps them build confidence not only in their reading but in themselves.

We meet the kids where they are at and help elevate them to where they want to go...

This year we decided our theme would be “overcoming obstacles.” We chose this theme especially because of all the hardship that has touched every family over the past year. As you’ll see each of our perks is named after a famous literary character who overcame incredible obstacles to achieve their goals and dreams. We want to inspire our kids to keep believing and keep trying no matter what!

ABOUT US

The Adventures of a Rogue Swan (TARS) is a ballet company that uses ballet to help children learn and grow. This outreach project focuses on literacy and is produced by Silent Fire Productions, a commercial ballet company that strives for new ways to introduce ballet to everyone, everywhere.

Children in our summer reading program are not required to read books about ballet but we have created a great summer reading list with wonderful stories about ballet, dancers, and other young heroes, and how they’ve overcome obstacles to reach their dreams - both in their home life and their career.

Diversity and inclusion is also hugely important to us, especially now, and we've worked very hard to create resources that reflect the diverse and ever changing makeup of children in America.

WHAT WE NEED & WHAT YOU GET

Donations cover the cost of prizes for the children participants and one-on-one support for them and their parents. In addition, for families who can't afford books your donation provides us with ways to help them get books.

Prizes include;

  • Ben & Jerry's Gift Card
  • Certificate of Completion
  • Special Summer 2021 Reading Program Patch/Sticker
  • Free Book from TARS book collection

Support includes;

  • Special intake meeting to set goals and better understand children's needs and interests
  • Virtual support throughout the program to check in and assist in goals being met
  • Fun reading and literacy activities for children to participate in
  • Documents to help parents to keep track of books read and process what was being read
  • Access to books

And.....a Virtual End of Summer Celebration Party!!

 

THE IMPACT

Reading is a superpower...

A recent study study published in American Education Research Journal, following students in grades 1 through 6 over five summers, showed more than half of students lost an average of 39% of their total school year gains during the summer months, also known as "summer slide." And this was before the pandemic...

The American Libraries Association states that the benefits to readers in a summer reading program include:

  • encouragement that reading become a lifelong habit
  • reluctant readers can be drawn in by the activities
  • reading over the summer helps children keep their skills up
  • the program can generate interest in the library and books
  • And it being summer, the program can just be good fun and provide an opportunity for family time.

Reading does so much for a child's confidence, cognitive skills but also their socio-emotional skills. Did you know...

"Reading helps to develop a child's empathy skills as they get enthralled in a book with a storyline that has a character that has to learn some lesson. Empathy skills are a vital component to having healthy relationships in society."

 

CHALLENGES

This program is also for reluctant readers who may need some additional encouragement to fall in love with reading. All need children need to feel they are being supported in their goals in order to achieve them and our challenge this summer is to make sure that each child in our program and their families get the specialized support they need to achieve their goals.

Thankfully we've had a bit of practice (about 20 years or so...) of working with kids!

We will be working with each family on an individual basis to address what their specific needs are and how we can address them.

 

THE TEAM

    Matina Banks ~ Director, Educator

    Matina is a ballerina, educator and producer born in Northern Virginia and raised in New York City. She started The Adventures of a Rogue Swan (TARS) after using the arts to teach in New York City public school, most especially in the Bronx. While working in the Bronx, she fell in love with the children she worked with but always felt heartbroken that she couldn't do more to help them - especially teaching them not to give up on themselves or their dreams. She also fell in love with literacy, reading and children's books and used reading as a way to help her students feel empowered and gain access to the world. After 20 years of teaching, she has shifted her focus to working on more outreach including starting this Summer Reading Program through TARS.

     

    Leah Court ~ Marketing, Graphic Design

    Leah is a UK based illustrator and graphic designer. As a lover of children's books, she values the importance of literacy and accessibility for all children. Ms. Court graduated from university in 2019 with a degree in Graphic Arts and will begin teacher training in Autumn 2021. From paper cut to digital illustrations she enjoys experimenting with a variety of media within her work. She loves working with colour and appreciates the effect it has on the message being communicated. Her interest in and curiosity for exploring and learning more about the world around her led her to join this project. In addition to working on her projects with The Adventures of a Rogue Swan, she does volunteer digital marketing for The National Trust of England. The National Trust is responsible for heritage conservation in the UK. For some of Leah's previous projects check out: https://leahcourt.wixsite.com/leahsgraphicarts

     

    OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

    Please spread the word! Whether you are able to donate or not, you probably know someone who would enjoy being a part of this great fundraiser.

    Sign up for the program! Do you know of a child who might benefit from our Summer Reading Program? You can get more information and register here.

    Check back for updates and more about this incredible project!
